editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The excellent comedy, called the old law: or a new way to please you. By Phil. Massinger. Tho. Middleton. William Rowley.

Acted before the King and Queen at Salisbury house, and at several other places, with great applause. Together with an exact and perfect catalogue of all the plays, with the author's names, and what are comedies, tragedies, histories, pastorals, masks, interludes, more exactly printed then ever before.
London, printed for Edward archer, at the sign of the Adam and Eve, in little Britain. 1656.

div.head: Persons of the play.

list.item: Creon, father to Simonides and Cleanthes.
Lisander husband to Eugenia and uncle to Cleanthes.
Antigona, mother to Simonides and Cleanthes.
Eugenia, wife to Lisander and mother to Parthenia.

div.stage: The scene Epire.

div.head: The old law.
Act. i. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter Simonides, and two lawyers.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Is the law firm sir?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: The law, what more firm sir,
More powerful, forcible, or more permanent?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By my troth sir,
I partly do believe it; conceive sir
You have indirectly answered my question.
I did not doubt the fundamental grounds
Of law in general, for the most solid,
But this particular law that me concerns
Now at the present, if that be firm and strong,
And powerful, and forcible, and permanent.
I am ● young man that has an old father.

sp.speaker: 2 lawyer
sp.l: Nothing more strong sir,
It is secundum statutum principis
Confirmatum cum voce senatum,
Et voce republicae, nay consummatum
Et exemplificatum, is it not in force
When divers have already tasted it
And paid their lives for penalty?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis true.
My father must be next, this day completes
Full fourscore years upon him.

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.l: He's here then
Sub poena statuti, hence I can tell him.
Truer then all the physicians in the world,
He cannot live out tomorrow; this is
The most certain climacterical year,
'tis passed all danger, for there's no scaping it:
What age is your mother sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Faith near her days to,
Wants some two of threescore.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: So, she'll drop away
One of these days to; he's a good age now
For those that have old parents, and rich inheritance.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And sir 'tis profitable for others too:
Are there not fellows that lie bedrid in their offices
That younger men would walk lustily in:
Churchmen, that even the second infancy
Hath silenced, yet hath spun out their lives so long
That many pregnant and ingenious spirits
Have languished in their hoped reversions,
And died upon the thought, and by your leave sir,
Have you not places filled up in the law
By some grave senators, that you imagine
Have held them long enough, and such spirits as you.
Were they removed, would leap into their dignities?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Dic quibus in terris et reis mihi magnus Apollo.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: But tell me faith you fair opinion:
Is't not a sound and necessary law
This (By the Duke) enacted ●

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Never did Greece
(Our 〈…〉 of brave philosophers)
Amongst all her N●m● the●●●nd lawgivers,
No● when she flourished in her seven fold sages,
(Whose living memory can never die)
Produce a law more grave and necessary.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm of that mind to.

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.l: I will maintain sir,
Draco's oligarchy that the government
Of community reduced into few
Framed a fair state; Solon's Crecopedi
That cut off poor men's debts to their rich creditors
Was good and charitable (But not full allowed.)
His sisaith●e did reform that error,
His honourable senate of Areopagitae,
Lycurgus was more loose, and gave too free
and licentious reins unto his discipline,
As that a young woman in her husband's weakness
Might choose her able friend to propagate;
That so the commonwealth might be supplied,
With hope of lusty spirits, Plato did err,
And so did Aristotle, allowing
Lewd and luxurious limits to their laws;
But now our Epire, our Epire's Evander,
Our noble and wise prince has hit the law
That all our predecessive students
Have missed unto their shame. Enter Cleanthes,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Forbear the praise sir.
'Tis in itself most pleasing, Cleanthes
O lad here's a spring for young plants to flourish,
The old trees must down kept the sun from us,
We shall rise now boy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Whether sir I pray?
To the bleak air of storms, among those trees,
Which we had shelter from.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes from our growth,
Our sap and livelihood and from our fruit,
W●●t 'tis not jubilee with thee yet, I think,
Thou lookest so sad o't, how old's thy father?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Jubilee, no indeed, 'tis a bad year with me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Prithee how old's thy father, than I can tell thee?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I know not how to answer you Simonides,
He's is too old being now exposed
Unto the rigor of a cruel edict,
And yet not old enough by many years,
'Cause I'd not see him go an hour before me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: These ve●● passions I speak to my father,
Come, come, here's none but friends here, we may speak
Our insides freely, these are lawyers man,
And shall be counsellors shortly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They shall be now sir,
And shall have large fees if they'll undertake
To help a good cause (For it wants assistance)
Bade ones (I know) they can insist upon.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: O sir. we must undertake of both parts,
but the good we have most good in.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray you say,
How do you allow of this strange edict?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Secundum justitiam, by my faith sir,
The happiest edict that ever was in Epire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What● to kill innocents sir, it cannot be,
It is no rule in justice there to punish.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: O sir,
You understand a conscience, but not law.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why sir, is there so main a difference?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: You'll never be good laywer if you understand not that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I think then 'tis the best to be a bad one.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Why sir, the very letter and the sense both
Do both o'erthrow you in this statute,
Which that speaks, that every man living to
Fourscore years, and women to threescore, shall then
Be cut off as fruitless to the republic,
And law shall finish what nature lingered at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And this suit shall soon be dispatched in law.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: It is so plain it can have no demur,
The church-book overthrows it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And so it does
The church book overthrows it if you read it well.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Still you run from the law into error:
You say it takes the lives of innocents,
I say no, and so says common reason:
What man lives to fourscore and women to three
That can die innocent?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A fine lawful evasion:
Good sir rehearse the full statute to me●

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Fie that's too tedious, you have already
The full sum in the brief relation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, amongst many words may be found contradictions,
And these men dare sue and wrangle with a statute,
If they can pick a quarrel with some error:

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.p: Listen sir, I'll gather it as brief as I can for you, anno primo evandri, be it (For the care and good of the common wealth for divers necessary reasons that we shall urge) thus peremptorily enacted

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A fair pretence if the reasons foul it not.

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.p: That all men living in our dominions of Epire in their decayed nature, to the age of four score, or women to the age of three score, shall on the same day be instantly put to death, by those means and instruments that a former proclamation had (To this purpose) through our said territories dispersed.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There was no women in this senate certain.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.p: That these men being passed their bearing arms, to aid and defend their country, passed their manhood and livelihood, to propagate any further issue to their posterity, and as well passed their counsels (Which overgrown gravity is now run into dotage) to assist their country, to whom in common reason, nothing should be so wearisome as their own lives, as it may be supposed is tedious to their successive heirs, whose times are spent in the good of their country, yet wanting the means to maintain it; and are like to grow old before their inheritance (Born to them) come to their necessary use, for the which are the women, for that they never were defence to their country, never by counsel admitted to the assist of government of their country, only necessary to the propagation of posterity, and now at the age of threescore to be passed that good, and all their goodness: it is thought f●t then a quarter abated from the more worthy member to be put to death as is before recited: provided that for the just and impartial execution of this our statute the example shall first begin in and about our court, which ourself will see carefully performed, and not for a full month following extend any further into our dominions: dated the sixth of the second month at our palace royal in Epire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A fine edict, and very fairly guilded
And is there no scruple in all these words,
To demur the law upon occasion?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Pox 'tis an unnecessary inquisition,
Prithee set him not about it.

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.l: Troth none sir,
It is so evident and plain a case
There is no succour for the defendant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Possible, can nothing help in a good case?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Faith sir I do think there may be a hole
Which would protract delay if not remedy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why there's some comfort in that good sir? speak it▪

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Nay you must pardon me for that sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Prithee do not,
It may open a wound to many sons and heirs
That may die after it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come sir, I know how to make you speak, will this doo●?

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: I will afford you my opinion sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray you repeat the literal words expressly
The time of death.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis an unnecessary question, prithee let it alone.

sp.speaker: 2. lawyer
sp.l: Hear his opinion, 'twill be fruitless sir.
That man at the age of four score, and women at threescore
Shall the same day be put to death.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Thus I help the man to twenty one years more,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That were a fair addition.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Mark it, sir we say man is not at age
Till he be one and twenty before his infancy
And adolescence, nor by that addition,
Fourscore he cannot be till a hundred and one.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O poor evasion!
He's fourscore years old sir,

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: That help● more sir
He begins to be old at fifty, so at fourscore,
He's but thirty years old, so believe it sir,
He may be twenty years in declination
And so long may a man linger and live bit

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The worst hope of safety that ere I heard,
Give him his fee again, 'tis not worth two deneers.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: There's no law for restitution of ●ees sir. Enter Creon and Antigona.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.l: No no sir, I meant it lost when 'twas given.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: No more good sir
Here are ears unnecessary for your doctrine.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: I have spoked out my fee and I have done sir.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: O my dear father!

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Tush meet me not in exclaims
I understand the worst and hope no better:
A fine law, if this hold, white heads will be cheap
And many watch men's places will be vacant
Forty of 'em I know my seniors,
that did due deeds of darkness to their country,
H●s watched 'em a good turn fort, and ta'en 'em
Napping now, the fewer hospitals will serve to,
Many may be used for stews and brothels
And those people will never trouble 'em to fourscore.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Can you play and sport with sorrow sir?

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Sorrow, for what Antigona? for my life,
My sorrows I have kept it so long well
With bringing it up unto so ill an end:
I might have gently lost it in my cradle,
Before my nerves and ligaments grew strong
To bind it faster to me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: For mine own sake
I should have been sorry for that.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: In my youth
I was a son d●●r● no coward in my age,
I never turned my back upon my foe,
I have felt nature's win●●●s sicknesses,
Yet ever kept a lively sap in me
To greet the cheerful spring of health again:
Dangers on horseback, on foot by water,
I have scaped to this day, and yet this day
Without all help of casual accidents
Is only deadly to me, 'cause it numbers
Fourscore years to me, where's the ●au●t now?
I cannot blame time, nature, nor my stars
Nor ought but tyranny, even Kings themselves
Have some times tasted an even fate with me,
He that has been a soldier all his days
And stood in personal opposition, 'gainst darts and arrows, the extremes of heat,
And pinching cold has treacherously at home
In his secured quiet by a villain's hand
Am basely lost in my star●s ignorance
And so must I die by a tyrant's sword.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: O say not so sir, it is by the law!

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: And what's that sir but the sword of tyranny
When it is brandished against innocent lives?
I'm now upon my death bed sir, and 'tis ●i●
I should unbosom my free conscience
And show the faith I die in, I do believe
'Tis tyranny that takes my life.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Would it were gone
By one means or other, what a long day
Will this be ere night?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Simonides.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Here sit — weeping.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Wherefore dost thou 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Cause you make no more haste to your end.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How can you question nature so unjustly?
I had a grandfather, and then had not you
True filial tears for him?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Hypocrite,
A disease of drought dry up all pity from him
That can dissemble pity with wet eyes

sp.speaker: Cre
sp.l: Be good unto your mother Simonides,
She must be now your care.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: To what end sir?
The bell of this sharp edict tolls for me
As it rings out for you, I'll be as ready
With one hours stay to go along with you.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Thou must not woman, there are years behind
Before thou canst set forward in this voyage,
And nature sure will now, be kind to all:
She has a quarrel in't, a cruel law
Seeks to prevent her, she'll therefore fight in't
And draw out life even to her longest thread
Thou art scarce fifty five.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: So many morrows,
Those five remaining years I'll turn to days
To hours or minutes for thy company,
'Tis fit that you and I being man and wife
Should walk together arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I hope they'll go together, I would they would i'faith,
Then would her thirds be saved to, the day goes away sir.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou have me gone Simonides?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O my heart, would you have me gone before you sir?
You give me such a deadly wound.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fine rascal.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Blemish my duty so with such a question,
Sir I would haste me to the Duke for mercy,
He that's above the law may mitigate
The rigor of the Law● how a good meaning
May be corrupted by misconstruction?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Thou corrupt'st mine, I did not think thou meanest so.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You were in the more error.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: The words wounded me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Twas pity thou diedst not on't.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I have been ransacking the helps of law
Conferring with these learned advocates,
If any scruple cause or wrested sense
Could have been found out to preserve your life,
It had been bought though with your full estate,
Your life's so precious to me, but there is none.

sp.speaker: 1. lawyer
sp.l: Sir we have canvased it from top to toe,
Turned it upside down, throw her on her side
Nay opened and dissected all her in●●oyles
Yet can find none, there's nothing to be hoped
But the Duke's mercy.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I know the hope of that,
He did not make the law for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Then to his hopeless mercy last I go,
I have so many presidents before me.
I must call it hopeless Antigona,
See me delivered up unto my death's man
And then we'll p●●t five years hence I'll look for thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I hope she'll not stay so long behind you.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Do not bate him an hour by grief and sorrow
Since there's a day prefixed, haste it not,
Suppose me sick Antigona, dying now
Any disease thou 〈◊〉 may be my end
Or when death's slow to come, say tyrants sendExeunt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Cleanthes if you want money, tomorrow use me,
I'll trust you while your father's dead. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why here's a villain,
Able to corrupt a thousand by example,
Does the kind root bleed out his livelihood
in parent distribution to his branches,
Adorning 〈◊〉 with all his glorious fruits,
Proud that his pride is seen when he's unseen,
And must not gratitude discend again
To comfort his old limbs in fruitless winter
Improvident, at least partial nature
Weak woman in this kind, who in thy last
Teeming still forgets the former, ever making
The burden of thy last throws the dearest
Darling; o yet in noble man reform it,
And make us better than those vegetives ,
Whose souls die within 〈◊〉; nature as thou art old,
If love and justice be not dead in thee,
Make some the pattern of thy piety,
Lest all do turn unnaturally against thee,
And thou be blamed for our oblivionsEnter Leonides and Hippolita.
And brush reluctations; it here's the ground
Whereon my filial faculties must build
An edifice of honour or of shame
To all mankind.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must avoid it sir:
If there be any love within yourself,
This is far more than fate of a lost game
That another venture may restore again;
It is your life which you should not subject
To any cruelty if you can preserve it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O dearest woman, thou hast now doubled
A thousand times thy nuptial dowry to me;
Why she whose love is but derived from me
Is gone before me in my debted duty.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Are you thinking such a resolution sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sweetest Hippolita what love taught say
To be so forward in so good a cause?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Mine own pity sir, did first instruct me
And then your love and power did both command me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They were all blessed angels to direct thee,
And take their counsel; how do you fare sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Never better Cleanthes, I have conceived
Such a new joy within this old bosom,
as I did never think would there have entered.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Joy call you it, alas 'tis sorrow sir,
The worst of sorrows, sorrow unto death.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Death, what's that Cleanthes, I thought not on't?
I was in contemplation of this woman.
'Tis all thy comfort son, thou hast in her
A treasure unvaluable, keep her safe;
When I die, sure 'twilbe a gentle death;
For I will die with wonder of her virtues,
Nothing else shall dissolve me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Twere much better sir,
Could you prevent their malice.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'll prevent 'em,
And die the way I told thee, in the wonder
Of this good woman. I tell thee there few men
Have such a child (I must thank thee for her)
That the stronger tie of wedlock should do more
Than nature in her nearest ligaments
Of blood and propagation, I should ne'er
Have begotten such a daughter of my own:
A daughter in law, law were above nature
Were there more such children.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This admiration
Helps nothing to your safety, think of that sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Had you heard her Cleanthes but labour
In the search of means to save my forfeit life,
And knew the wise and sound preservations
That she found out, you would redouble all
My wonder in your love to her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The thought,
The very thought claims all that from me,
And she's now possessed of it, but good sir,
If you have ought received from her advice,
Let's follow it, or else let's better think,
And take the surest course.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I'll tell thee one,
She counsels me to fly my severe country,
Turn all into treasure, and there build up
My decaying fortunes in a safer soil,
where Epire's law cannot claim 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And sir, I apprehend it as safest course
And may be easily accomplished;
Let us be all most expeditious
Every country where we breath will be our own,
On better soil; heaven is the roof of all,
And now as Epire's situate by this law,
There is twixt us and heaven a dark eclipse.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O then avoid it sir, these sad events
Follow those black predictions.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I prithee peace,
I do allow thy love Hippolita,
But must not follow it as counsel, child;
I must not shame my country for the law:
This country here hath bred me, brought me up,
And shall I now refuse a grave in her?
I'm in my second infancy and children
Ne'er sleep so sweetly in their nurse's cradle.
As in their natural mothers.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.l: I but sir,
She is unnatural, than the stepmother
Is to be preferred before her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tush, she shall
Allow it me despite of her entrails;
Why do you think how far from judgement 'tis
That I should travel forth to seek a grave
That is already digged for me at home,
Nay perhaps find it in my way to seek it?
How have I then sought a repentant sorrow?
For your dear loves how have I banished you
From your country ever with my base attempt
How have I beggared you in wasting that
Which only for your sakes I b●●d together,
Buried my name in Epire which I built
Upon this frame to live for ever in.
What a base coward shall I be to fly
From that enemy which every minute meets me?
And thousand odds he had not long vanquished me
Before this hour of battle, sly my death
I will not be so false unto your states,
Nor fainting to the man that's yet in me,
I'll meet him bravely, I cannot (This knowing) fear
That when I am gone hence I shall be there,
Come, I have days of preparation left.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Good sir, hear me●
I have a genius that has prompted me,
And I have almost formed it into words,
'Tis done, pray you observe 'em, I can conceal you
And yet not leave your country.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tush, it cannot be
Without a certain peril on's all.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Danger must be hazarded rather than accept
A sure destruction: you have a lodge sir,
So far remote from way of passengers,
That seldom any mortal eye does greet with it,
And yes so sweetly situate with thickets
Built with such cunning labyrinths within,
As if the provident heavens foreseeing cruelty
Had bid you frame it to this purpose only.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Fie, fie, 'tis dangerous, and treason to,
To abuse the law,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis holy care sir,
Of your dear life, which is your own to keep,
But not your own to lose, either in will
Or negligence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Call you it treason sir,
I had been then a traitor unto you,
Had I forgotten this, beseech you accept of it,
It is secure and a duty to yourself.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What a coward will you make me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You mistake
'Tis noble courage, now you fight with death,
And yield not to him till you stoop under him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This must needs open to discovery,
And then what torture follows?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: By what means sir?
Why there's but one body in all this counsel,
which cannot betray itself, we two are one,
One soul, one body, one heart, that think all one though●,
And yet we two are not completely one,
But as have derived myself from you,
Who shall betray us where there is no second?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must not mistrust my faith though my sex
Plead weak and frailty for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O I dare not!
But where's the means that must make answer for me
I cannot be lost without a full account,
And what must pay that reckoning?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O sir, we will
Keep solemn obits for your funeral;
We'll seem to weep, and seem to joy withal
That death so gently has prevented you
The law's sharp rigor, and this no mortal ear
Shall participate the knowledge of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
This will be a sportive fine demur
If the error be not found.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray doubt of none
Your company and best provision
Must be no further furnished then by us,
And in the interim your solitude
May converse with heaven, and fairly prepare
Which was too violent and raging
Thrown headlong on you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Still there are some doubts
Of the discovery, yet I do allow't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Will you not mention now the cost and charge
Which will be in your keeping?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That will be somewhat
Which you might save to.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: With his will against him;
What foe is more to man then man himself?
Are you resolved sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am Cleanthes:
If by this means I do get a reprieve
and cozen death a while, when he shall come
Armed in his own power to give the blow,
I'll smile upon him then, and laughing go. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. ii. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter Duke ●3. Courtiers and executioner.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Executioner.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How did old Diocles take his death?

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: As weeping brides receive their joys at night my lord,
With trembling yet with patience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why 'twas well.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Nay I knew my father would do well my lord.
When ere ●e came to die, I'd that opinion of him.
Which made me the more willing to part from him;
He was not fit to live i'th world indeed any time these
Ten years my lord.
But I would not say so much.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, you did not well in●,
For he that's all spent is ripe for death at all hovers,
And does but trifle time out,

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Troth my lord,
I would I had known your mind nine years ago,

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.l: Our law is fourscore years, because we judge
Dotage complete then, as unfruitfulness
In women at threescore, marry if the son
Can within compass bring good solid proofs
Of his own father's weakness and unfitness
To live or sway the living though he want five
Or ten years of his number, that's not it,
His defect makes him fourscore, and 'tis fit
he dies when he deserves, for every ●ct
Is in effect then when the cause is ripe.

sp.speaker: 2. courtier
sp.l: An admirable prince how rarely he talks?
O that we'd known th●s lads, what a time did we endure
In two penny commons? and in boots twice vamped.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Now we have two pairs a week, and yet not thankful,
'Twill be a fine world for them sirs that come after as.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.p: I and they knew't. 2. Cou peace let them never know't.

sp.speaker: 3. Courtesan
sp.p: A pox the●e be young heirs will soon smelled out.

sp.speaker: 2. courtier
sp.l: 'Twill come to 'em by instinct man, may your grace
Never be old, you stand so well for youth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why now methinks our court looks like a spring,
Sweet, fresh, and fashionable, now the old weeds are gone.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.p: 'Tis as a court should be: gloss and good clothes,
My lord no matter for merit and herein your law proves a provident act my lord, when men pass not the palsy of their tongues, nor color in their cheeks.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But women by that law should live long,
For they're ne●r passed it.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: It will have heats though when they see the painting
Go an inch deep ith' wrinkle, and take up
A box more than their gossips, but for men my lord
That should be the sole bravery of a palace,
To walk with hollow eyes and long white beards,
(As if a pierce dwelled in a land of goats)
With clothes as if they sat upon their backs on purpose
To arraign a fashion and condemn't to exile
Their pockets in their sleeves, as if they laid
Their ear to avarice, and heard the devil whisper;
Now ours lie downward here close to the flank,
Right spending pockets as a son's should be
That lives i●h fashion, where our diseased fathers
Would with the sciatica and aches
Brought up your poind hose first, which ladies laughed at,
Giving no reverence to the place, (Lies ruined,)
They love a doublet that's three hours a buttoning,
And sits so close makes a man groan again,
And his soul matter half a day; yet these are those
That carry sway and worth, pricked up in clothes,
why should we fear our rising?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You but wrong
Our kindness, and your own deserts to doubt on't,
Has not our law made you rich before your time?
Our countenance then can make you honourable.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: We'll spare for no cost sir to appear worthy.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why you're i'th noble way then, for the most
Are but appearers, worth itself it is lost
And bravery stands fort. Enter Creon, Antigona and Simonides.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: Look, look, who comes here
I smell death and another courtier,
Simonides.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Push, I'm not for you yet,
Your companies too costly, after the old man's
Dispatched I shall have time to talk with you,
I shall come into the fashion ye shall see too
After a day or two, in the mean time
I am not for your company.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Old Creon you have been expected long.
Sure you're above fourscore.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Upon my life
Not four and twenty hours my lord, I searched
The church book yesterday, does your grace think
I'd let my father wrong the law my lord?
'Twere pity a'my life then, no your act
Shall not receive a minute's wrong by him
While I live sir, and he's so just himself too
I know he would no offer't, here he stands.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: 'Tis just I die indeed my lord, for I confess
I'm troublesome to life now, and the state
Can hope for nothing worthy from me now,
Either in force or counsel, I've o'late
Employed myself quite from the world, and he that once
Begins to serve his maker faithfully
Can never serve a worldly prince well after,
'Tis clean another way.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: O give not confidence
To all he speaks my lord in his own injury!
His preparation only for the next world
Makes him talk wildly to his wrong of this,
He is not lost in judgement.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She spoils all again.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Deserving any way for state employment.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mother.

sp.speaker: Anti
sp.l: His very household laws prescribed at home by him
Are able to conform 7. Christian kingdoms,
They are so wise and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Mother, I say.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I know your laws extend not to desert sir,
But to unnecessary years, and my lord
His are not such, though they show white, they're worthy,
Judicious, able, and religious.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll help you to a courtier of nineteen, mother.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Away unnatural.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then I am no fool I'm sure,
Fo● to be natural at such a time
Were a fool ●s part ind●ed.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Your grace's pity sir,
An 'tis but fit and just.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: ●h● law my lord,
And that's the justest way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: W●●l said father efaith.
Thou wert ever juster than my mother still.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come hither sir.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What are those orders?

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: Worth observation sir,
So please you hear them read.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: The woman speaks she knows not what my lord:
He make a law, poor man he bought a table indeed,
Only to learn to die by't; there's the business now
Wherein there ●re some precepts for a son to,
How he should learn to live, but I ne'er looked upon't:
For when he's dead I shall live well enough,
And keep a better table than that I trow●

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And is that all sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: All I vow my lord,
save a few running admonitions
Upon cheese trenchers, as take heed of whoring, shun it;
'Tis like a cheese too strong of the rennet,
And such calf's maws of wit and admonition
Good to catch mice with, but not sons and heirs,
They're not so easily caught.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Agent for death.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: Your will my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Take hence that pile of years
Before surfeit with unprofitable age
And with the rest from the high promontory,
Cast him into the sea.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: 'Tis noble justice.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: 'Tis cursed tyranny.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Peace, take heed mother, you have but a short time to be cast down yourself, and let a young courtier do't, and you be wise, in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Anti
sp.l: Hence slave.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well seven and fifty,
You've but three years to scoed, then comes your payment,

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: Simonides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Push, I am not brave enough to hold you talk yet,
Give a man time. I have a suit a making. Recorders.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: We love thy form first, brave clothes will come man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll make 'em come else with a mischief to em●
As other gallants do, that have less left 'em.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Hark whence those sounds, what's that?

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: Some funeralRecorders. Enter Cleanthes and Hipolita with a hears
It seems my lord, and young Cleanthes follows.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cleanthes.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: 'Tis my lord, and in the place
Of a chief mourner to, but strangely habited.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yet suitable to his behaviour, mark it,
He comes all the way smiling, do you observ't?
I never saw a corpse so joyfully followed,
Light colours and light cheeks, who should this be?
'Tis ● thing worth resolving.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: One belike that doth participate
In this our present joy.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cleanthes,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He laughed outright now,
Was ever such a contrariety seen
In natural courses yet, nay professed openly?

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: I ha' known a widow laugh closely my lord
Under her handkercher, when tother part of her old face has w●●
Like rain in sunshine, but all the face to laugh apparently
Was never seen yet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes mine did once.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis of a heavy time the joyfull'st day
That ever son was born to.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How can that be▪

sp.speaker: Cl●an.
sp.l: I joy to make it plain, my father's dead.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Old Leonides.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: In his last month dead,
He beguiled cruel law the sweetliest
That ever age was blessed to,
It grieves me that a tear should fall upon't,
Being a thing so joyful; but his memory
Will work it out I see; when his poor heart broke
I did not so much but leapt for joy,
So mountingly I touched the stars methought ,
I would not hear of blacks I was so light●
But chose a colour orient, like my mind,
For blacks are often such dissembling mourners,
There is no credit given to't, it has lost
All reputation by false sons and widows;
Now I would have men know what I resemble,
A truth indeed, 'tis joy clad like a joy,
Which is more honest than a cunning grief
That's only faced with sables for a show,
But gawdy hearted; when I saw death come
So ready to deceive you, sir forgive me,
I could not choose but be entirely merry,
And yet to see now of a sudden
Naming but death, I show myself a mortal,
That's never constant to one passion long;
I wonder whence that tear came when I smiled,
In the production on't, sorrows a thief,
That can when joy looks on steal forth a grief,
But gracious leave my lord, when I have performed
My last poor duty to my father's bones,
I shall return your servant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well perform it,
The law is satisfied, they can but die,
And by his death Cleanthes you gain well,
A rich and fair revenue.Flourish

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I would I had e'en another father, condition he did the like

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have passed it bravely, now how blessed was I
To have the dim sight, now 'tis confirmed
Passed fear or doubts confirmed, on on I say,
He that brought me to man I bring to clay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm wrapped now in a contemplation,
Even at the very sight of yonder hearse,
I do but think what a fine thing 'tis now
To live and follow some seven uncles thus,
As many cousin germane, and such people
That will leave legacies, a pox I'd see 'em hanged else ere I'd follow
One of them, and they could find the way now I've enough to begin to be horrible covetous.

div.stage: Enter Butler, tailor, baily, cook, coachman, and footman.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: We come to know your worship's pleasure sir,
Having long served your father, how your good will
Stands towards our entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Not a jot i'faith:
sp.p: My father wore cheap garments, he might do't, I shall have all my clothes come home tomorrow, they will eat up all you, and there were more of you sirs; to keep you six at livery and still munching.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Why I'm a tailor, you've most need of me sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Thou mad'st my father's clothes that I confess,
But what son and heir will have his father's tailor
Unless he have a mind to be well laughed at? Thou'st been so used to wide long side things, that when I come to truss I shall have the waste of my doublet lie upon my buttocks, a sweet sight.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I a butler.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There's jest need of thee fellow, I shall ne'er drink at home, I shall be so drunk abroad.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But a cup of small beer will do well next morning sir

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I grant you, but what need I keep so big a knave for a cup of small beer?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Butler you have your answer, marry sir a cook,
I know your mastership cannot be without.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The more ass art thou to think so, for what should I do with a mountebank, no drink in my house, the banishing the butler might have been a warning for thee, unless thou meanst to choke me.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Ith' mean time you have choked me, methinks .

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.l: These are superfluous vanities indeed,
And so accounted of in these days sir,
But then your bailiff to receive your rends.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I prithee hold thy tongue fellow, I shall take a course to spend 'em faster than thou canst reckon 'em, 'tis not the rends must serve my turn, unless I mean to be laughed at, if a man should be seen out of slash me, let him never look to be a right gallant: but sirrah with whom is your business?

sp.speaker: Coach
sp.l: Your good mastership.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You have stood silent all this while, like men
That know their strengths i'these days, none of you
Can want employment, you can win me wagers
Footman in running races.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.l: I dare boast it sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And when my bets are all come in and store
Then coachman you can hurry me to my whore.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: I'll ●i●ke 'em into foam else.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Speaks brave matter,
And I'll firk some to, or't shall cost hot water.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: Why hears an age to make a cook a ruffian, and scald the devil indeed, do strange mad things, make mutton pasties of dog's flesh, back snal●es for lamprey pies, and cats for coneys:

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Come will you be ruled by a butler's advice once? for we must make up our fortunes somewhere now as the case stands, le●s ●en therefore go seek out widows of nine and fifty and we can, that's within a year of their deaths, and so we shall be sure to be quickly rid of 'em, for ● years enough of conscience to be
troubled with a wife for any man living.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Oracle butler, oracle butler, he puts down all the doctors a'th name. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, and Parthenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Parthenia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Mother.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I shall be troubled
This six months with an old clog, would the law
Had been cut one year shorter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Did you call forsooth.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes, you must make some spoon meat for your father,
And warm three night caps for him, out upon't
The mere conceit turns a young woman's stomach,
His slippers must be warmed in August too,
And his gown girt to him in the very dog-days
When every mastiff lo●s ou●s tongue for heat,
Would not this vex a beauty of 19. now?
Alas I shall be tumbling in cold baths now
Under each arm pit a fi●e bean flower bag
To screw out whiteness when I list,
And some seven of the properest men ith' dukedom,
Making a banquet ready ith' next room for me,
Where he that gets the first kiss is envied
And stands upon his guard a fortnight after;
This is a life for nineteen, but 'tis justice
For old men, whose great acts stand in their minds
And nothing in their bodies, do never think
A woman young enough for their desire,
And we young wenches that have mother wits
And love to marry muck first, and man after,
Do never think old men are old enough
That we may soon be rid on 'em there's our quittance;
I have wasted for the happy hour this two year
And if death be so unkind still to let him live
All that time I am lost. Enter courtiers.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Young lady.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Oh sweet precious bud of beauty!
Troth she smells over all the house methinks .

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: The sweet briers but a counterfeit to her●
it does exceed you only in the prickle,
But that it shall not long if you'll be ruled Lady●

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What means this sudden visitation gentlemen?
So passing well performed too, whose your milliner?

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Love and thy beauty widow.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Widow sir.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: 'Tis sure and that's as good, in troth we're suitors
We come a-wooing wench, plain dealings best.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A wooing, what before my husband's dead?

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Let's lose no time, 6. months will have an end you know,
I know't by all the bonds that ere I made yet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: That's a sure knowledge, but it holds not here sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.p: Do not you know the craft of your young tumblers? That you wed an old man, you think upon another husband as you are marrying of him, we knowing your thoughts made bold to see you. Enter Simonides, coachman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How wondrous right he speaks 'twas my thought indeed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By your leave sweet widow, do you lack any gallants?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Widow again, 'tis a comfort to be called so.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Who's this Simonides.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Brave Sim i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Coachman.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Have an especial care of my new mares,
They say sweet widow he that loves a horse well
Must needs love a widow well, when dies thy husband?
Is't not July next.

sp.speaker: ●ug
sp.l: O you're too hot sir!
Pray cool yourself and take September with you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: September o I was but two bows wide.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Mr. Simonides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I can entreat you gallants, I'm in fashion too. Ent. Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Ha, whence this herd of folly, what are you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well willers to your wife, pray tend your book sir,
We have nothing to say to you, you may go die,
For here be those in place that can supply.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: What's thy wild business here?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Old man, I'll tell thee,
I come to beg the reversion of thy wife,
I think these gallants be of my mind too, but thou art but ● dead
Man, therefore what should a man do talking with thee,
Come widow stand to your tickling.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Impious blood hounds.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let the ghost talk, ne'er mind him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Shames of nature.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Alas poor ghost, consider what the man is.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Monster's unnatural, you that have been covetous
Of your own father's deaths, gape ye for mine now?
Cannot a poor old man that now can reckon
E'en all the hours he has to live, live quiet
For such wild beasts as these, that neither hold
A certainty of good within themselves,
But scatter others comforts that are ripened
For holy uses? is hot youth so hasty
It will not give an old man leave to die?
And leave a widow first, but will make one
The husband looking on, may your destructions
Come all in hasty figures to your souls,
Your wealth depart in haste, to overtake
Your honesties, that died when you were infants.
May your male seed be hasty spend thrifts too?
Your daughter's hasty sinners and diseased
Ere they be thought at years to welcome misery,
And may you never know what leisure is
But at repentance: I am too uncharitable
Too foul, I must go cleanse myself with prayers;
These are the plagues of fondness to old men
We're punished home with what we dote upon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: So so, the ghost is vanished now, your answer lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Excuse me gentlemen, 'twere as much impudence
In me to give you a kind answer yet.
As madness to produce a churlish one.
I could say now, come a month hence sweet gentlemen,
Or two or three, or when you will indeed,
But I say no such thing. I set no time
Nor is it mannerly to deny any,
I'll carry an even hand to all the world,
Let other women make what haste they will,
what's that to me, but I profess unfeignedly
I'll have my husband dead before I marry,
Ner● look for other answer at my hands gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Would he were hanged for my part look for other.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I'm at a word

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And I'm at a blow then,
I'll lay you o'th lips and leave you.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Well struck Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He that dares say he'll mend it, I'll strike him.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: He would betray himself to be a brother
That goes about to mind it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you know my mind, I bar you not my house,
But if you choose out hours more seasonably
You may have entertainment.

div.stage: Enter Parthenia.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What will she do hereafter when sh' is a widow,
Keeps open house already? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How now girl?

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Those feathered fools that hither took their flight,
Have grieved my father much.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Speak well of youth wench
While th●●st a day to live; 'tis youth must make thee,
And when youth fails, wise women will make it;
But always take age first to make thee rich:
That was my counsel ever, and then youth
Will make thee sport enough all thy life after.
'Tis time's policy wench▪ what is't to bide
A little hardness for a pair of years or so,
A man whose only strength lies in his breath,
Weakness in all parts else, thy bedfellow
A cough o'th' lungs, or say a wheening matter,
Then shake off chains, and dance all thy life after.

sp.speaker: Parth.
sp.l: Every ●n● to their likings but I say
An honest man's worth all, be he young or grey,
Yonder's my cousin.

div.stage: Enter Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: A●t I must use thee now,
Dissembling is the best help for a virtue
That ever woman had, it saves their credit often.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now cousin,
What weeping?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Can you blame me when the time
Of my dear love and husband now draws on;
I study funeral rears against the day
I must be a sad widow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: In troth Eugenia I have cause to weep to,
But when I visit, I come comfortably,
And look to be so quited, yet more sobbing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O the greatest part of your affliction's past,
The worst of mine's to come, I have one to die,
Your husband's father is dead, and fixed
In his eternal peace, passed the sharp tyrannous blow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must use patience coz.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tell me of patience.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You have example fort in me and many.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yours was a father in law, but mine a husband
On for a woman that could love and live
With an old man, mine is a jewel cousin,
So quietly he lies by one, so still.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alas! I have a secret lodged within me
Which now will out, in pity I can't hold.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: One that will not disturb me in my sleep
After a whole month together, less it be
With those diseases age is subject to,
As aches, coughs, and pains, and these heaven knows
Against his will too, he's the quietest man,
Especially in bed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Be comforted.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: How can I lady?
None knows the terror of an husband's loss
But they that fear to lose him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fain would I keep it in, but 'twill not be,
She is my kinswoman, and I'm pitiful,
I must impart a good if I know't once,
To them that stand in need on't, I'm like one
Loves not to banquet with a joy alone,
My friends must partake too, prithee cease cousin
if your love be so boundless, which is rare
In a young woman in these days, I tell you,
To one so much passed service as your husband,
There is a way to beguile law, and help you,
My husband found it out first.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O sweet cousin!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You may conceal him, and give out his death
Within the time, order his funeral too;
We had it so for ours, I praise heaven fort,
And he's alive and safe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: O blessed coz,
How thou revivest me?

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: We daily see
The good old man, and feed him twice a day,
Methinks it is the sweetest joy to cherish him,
That ever life yet showed me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: So should I think
A dainty thing to nurse an old man well.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And then we have his prayers and daily blessing.
And we two live so lovingly upon't,
His son and I, and so contentedly,
You cannot think unless you tasted on't.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No I warrant you, o loving cousin,
What a great sorrow hast thou eased me of?
A thousand thanks go with thee.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I have a suit to you, I must not have you weep when I am gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No, if I do near trust me: easy fool,
Thou hast put thyself into my power for ever:
Take heed of angering of me; I conceal,
I fain a funeral, I keep my husband,
Lass I have been thinking any time these two years
I have kept him too long already.
I'll go count o'er my suitors, that's my business,
And prick the man down, I ha' six months to do't,
But could dispatch him in one, were I p●t to't. Exit.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. i.
div.stage: Enter the clown and clerk.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You have searched o●e the parish chronicles sir?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have found out the true age and date of the party you wot on.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Pray you be covered sir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When you have showed me the way sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O sir remember yourself, you are a clerk.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A small clerk sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Likely to be the wiser man sir, for your greatest clarks are not always so, as 'tis reported.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You are a great man in the parish sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I understand myself so much the better sir, for all the best in the parish pay duties to the clerk, and I would owe you none sir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Since you'll have it so, I'll be the first to hide my head.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Mine is a cap-case now to our business in your hand, good luck I hope, I long to be resolved.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Look you sir, this is that cannot deceive you.
This is the dial that goes ever true;
You may say ipse dixit upon this witness,
And 'tis good in law too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Pray you let's bear what it speaks.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mark sir, Agatha the daughter of pollux, this is your wife's name, and the name of her father, born.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Whose daughter say you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The daughter of Poll●x

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I take it his name was Bollux.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Pollux the orthography I assure you sir, the word is corrupted else.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Well on sir of Pollux, now come on Castor.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Born in an. 1540. and now 'tis 99. by 〈◊〉 infallible record sir (Let me see) she is now just 59. and 〈◊〉 but on.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I am sorry 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why sir? alas 'tis nothing, 'tis but so many months, so many weeks, so many —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do not deduct it to days 'twill be the more tedious, and to measure it by hour glasses were intolerable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do not think on it sir, half the time goes away in sleep, 'tis half the year in nights.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O you mistake me neighbour, I am loath to leave the good old woman. if she were gone now it would not grieve me, for what is a year alas but a lingering torment? and were it not better she were out of her pain, 'tmust needs be a grief to us both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I would I knew how to ease you neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You speak kindly truly, and if you say but amen to it, (Which is a word that I know you are perfect in) it might be done, cla●ks are the most indifferent honest men, for to the marriage of your enemy, or the burial of your friend, the curses or the blessings ●o you are all one, you say amen to all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With a better will to the one then the other neighbour, but I shall be glad to say amen to any thing might do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: There is first something above your duty, now I would have you set forward the clock a little, in to help the old woman out of her pain.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I will speak to the sexton for that, but the day will go never the faster for that.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O neighbour you do not conceit me, not the Jack of the clockhouse the hand of the dial I mean, come, I know you being a great clerk, cannot choose but have the art to cast a figure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Never indeed neighbour, I never had the judgement to c●st a figure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll show you on the back side of your book, look you, what figures this.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Four with a cipher that's forty.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: So forty, what's this now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The cipher is turned into 9. by adding the tail which makes forty nine.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Very well understood, what is't now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The 4. is turned into 3. 'tis now thirty nine.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Very well understood, and can you do this again?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O easily sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A wager of that, let me see the place of my wife's age again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Look you sir 'tis here 1540.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Forty drachmas, you do not turn that forty into thirty nine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A match with you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Done, and you shall keep stakes yourself there they are.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A firm match, but stay sir now I consider it, I shall add a year to your wife's age, let me see Scirophon the 17. and now 'tis H●catomcaon the 11. if I alter this your wife will have but a month to live by the law.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: That's all one sir, either do it or pay me my wager.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Will you lose your wife before you lose your wager?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A man may get two wives before half so much money by 'em, will you do't?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I hope you will conceal me for 'tis flat corruption.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay sir I would have you keep counsel, for I lose my money by't and should be laughed at for my labour, if it should be known.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well sir, there 'tis done, is perfect 39. as can be found in black and white but mum sir, there's danger in this figure casting.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ay sir, I know that better men than you have been thrown over the bar for as little, the best is, you can be but thrown out of the belfry.

div.stage: Enter the cook, the tailor, bailiff, and Butler.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lock close here comes company, asses have ears as well as pitchers.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: O Gnothos, how is't? here's a trick of discarded cards of us, we were ranked with coats as long as our old master lived.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And is this then the end of serving men?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Yes faith, this is the end of serving men, a wise man were better serve one god then all the men in the world.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Twas well! spoke of a cook, and are all fallen into fasting days and ember weeks, that cooks are out of use?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: And all tailors will be cut into lists and shreds, if this world hold, we shall grow both out of request.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And why not butlers as well as tailors, if they can go naked, let 'em neither eat nor drink.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
That's strange methinks , a lord should turn away his
tailor of all men, and how dost thou Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I do so so, but indeed all our wants are long of this publican my lords bailiff, for had he been rent gatherer still, our places had held together still, that are now seam rent, nay cracked in the whole piece.

sp.speaker: B●l.
sp.p: Sir, if my lord had not sold his lands that claim his rends, I should still have been the rent gatherer.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: The truth is, except the co●thman, and the footman, all serving men are out of request.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay say not so, for you were never in more request than now; for requesting is but a kind of a begging, for when you say I beseech your worship's charity, 'tis all one if you say I request i●● and in that kind of requesting, I am sure serving men were never in more request.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Troth he says true, well let that pass, we are upon a better adventure. I see Gnothos you have been before us, we came to deal with this merchant for some commodities.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With me sir any thing that I can.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Nay we have looked out our wives already, marry to you we come to know the princes, that is to know their ages for so much reverence we bear to age, that the more aged, they shall be the more dear to us.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: The truth is every man has laid by his widow, so they be lame enough, blind enough, and old, 'tis good enough.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I keep the town stock, if you can but name 'em, I can tell their ages today.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We can tell their fortunes to an hour then.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Only you must pay for turning of the leaves.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: O bountifully, come mine first!

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The butler before the cook while you live, there's few that eat before they drink in a morning.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Nay then the tailor puts in his needle of priority, for men do clothe themselves before they either drink or eat.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: I will strive for no place, the longer ere I marry my wife, the older she will be, and nearer her end and my ends.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I will serve you all gentlemen if you will have patience.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I commend your modesty sir, you are a bailiff whose place is to come behind other men, as it were in the bum of all the rest.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p:
So sir, and you were about this business too, seeking out
for a widow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alack no sir, I am a married man, and have those cares upon me that you would fain run into.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: What an old rich wife, any man in this age desires such a care.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Troth sir I'll put a venture with you if you will, I have a lusty old Queen to my wife, sound of wind and limb, yet I'll give out to take three for one● at the marriage of my second wife.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: Ay sir, but how near is she to the law?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Take that at hazard sir, there must be time you know to get a new: unsight, unseen, I take 3. to one.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: Two to one I'll give if she have but two teeth in her head.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A match, there's five drachmas for ten at my next wife.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I shall be fitted bravely, fifty eight and upwards, 'tis but a year and a half, and I may chance make friends, and beg a year of the Duke.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Hey boys I am made sir butler, my wife that shall be wants but two months of her time, it shall be one ere I marry her, and then ●h● next will be a honey moon.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I out strip you all, I shall have but six weeks of Lent, if I get my widow, and then comes eating tide plump and gorgeous.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This tailor will be a man if ever there were any.

sp.speaker: B●y
sp.p: Now comes my turn, I hope goodman finis, you that are still at the end of all with a so be it, well now sirs, do you venture there as I have done? and I'll venture hereafter you, good luck I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amen sir.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: That deserves a fee already, there 'tis, please me and have a better.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amen sir.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: How two for one at your next wife, is the old one living?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You have a fair match, I offer you no foul one, if death make not haste to call her, she'll make none to go to him.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I know her, she's a lusty woman, I'll take the venture.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: There's five drachmes for ten at my next wife.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A bargain.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Nay then we'll be all merchants give me.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: And me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What has the bailiff sped?

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: I am content, but none of you shall know my happiness.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: As well as any of you all believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: O clerk you are to speak last always.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'll remember't hereafter sir▪ you have done with me gentlemen? Enter wife.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: For this time honest register.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Fare you well then, if you do, I'll cry amen to't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Look you sir is not this your wife?

sp.speaker: C●o.
sp.p: My first wife sir.

sp.speaker: B●t.
sp.p: Nay then we have made a good match on't, if she have no froward disease, the woman may live this dozen years by her age.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I'm afraid she's broken winded, she holds silence so long.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: We'll now leave our venture to the event, I must a-wooing .

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I'll but buy me a new dagger, and overtake you.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: So we must all, for he that goes a-wooing to a widow without a weapon will never get her. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O wife, wife!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What ●yle you man you speak so passionately.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis for thy sake sweet wife, who would think so lusty an old woman, with reasonable good teeth, and her tongue in as perfect use as ever it was, should be so near her time, but the fates will have it so?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What's the matter man, you do amaze me?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Thou art not sick neither I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Not that I know of sure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What pity 'tis a woman should be so near her end, and yet not sick●

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Near her end man, tush I can guess at that,
I have years good yet of life in the remainder,
I want two yet at least of the full number,
Than the law I know craves impotent and useless
And not the ●ble women.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
I alas I see thou hast been repairing time ●s well as thou
couldst, the old wrinkles are well filled up, but the vermilion is seen too thick, too thick, and I read what's written in thy forehead, it agrees with the church book.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Have you sought my age man, and I prithee how is it?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I shall but discomfort thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Not at all man, when there's no remedy, I will go though unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 1539. Just it agrees with the book, you have about a year to prepare yourself.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out al●s, I hope there's more than so, but do you not think a reprieve might be gotten for half a score, and 'twere but five year, I would not care, an able woman ( methinks ) ●ere to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I to be pitied, but not helped, no hope of that, for indeed women have so blemished their own reputations nowadays , that it is thought the law will meet them at fifty very shortly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marry the heavens forbid.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: There's so many of you that when you are old become witches, some profess physic, and kill good subjects faster than a burning favour; and than schoolemistresses of the sweet sin, which commonly we call bawds innumerable of that sort: for these and such causes 'tis thought they shall not live above fifty.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I man but this hurts not the good old women.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: i'faith you are so like one another, that a man cannot distinguish 'em now; were I an old woman I would desire to go before my time, and offer myself willingly, 2. or 3. years before; o those are brave women and worthy to be commended of all men in the world that when their husbands die they run to be burned to death with 'em, there's honour and credit, give me half a dozen such wives.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I if her husband were dead before, 'twere a reasonable request, if you were dead I could be content to be so.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Fie, that's not likely, for thou hadst two husbands before me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou wouldst not have me die, wouldst thou husband?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
No I do not speak to that purpose, but I say what credit it were for me and thee, if thou wouldst, than thou shouldst never be suspected for a witch, a physician, a bawd, or any of those things, and then how daintily should I mourn for thee, how bravely
should I see thee buried, when alas if he goes before it cannot choose but be a great grief to him to think he has not seen his wife well buried, there be such virtuous women in the world, but too few, too few who desire to die 7. years before their time with all their hearts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have not the heart to be of that mind, but indeed husband I think you would have me gone.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No alas I speak but for your good and your credit, for when a woman may die quickly, why should she go to law for her death, alack I need not wish thee gone, for thou hast but a short time to stay with me, you do not know how near 'tis, it must out, you have but a month to live by the law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out alas.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay scarce so much.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O, o, o, my heart! Swoons.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I so, if thou wouldst go away quietly 'twere sweetly done, and like a kind wife, lie but a little longer and the bell shall toll for thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O my heart, but a month to live.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas why wouldst thou come back again for a month, I'll throw her down again, o woman 'tis not three weeks, I think a fortnight is the most.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay then I am gone already. Swoons.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I would make haste to the sexton now, but I'm afraid the tolling of the bell will wake her again; if she be so wise as to go now, she stirs again, there's two lives of the nine gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O wouldst not thou help to recover me husband?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas, I could not find in my heart to hold thee by thy nose, or box thy cheeks, it goes against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I will not be thus frighted to my death,
I'll search the church record a fortnight
'Tis too little of conscience, I cannot be so near,
O time if thou beest kind lend me but a year. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
What a spite's this, that a man cannot persuade his wife to die in any time with her good will, I have another bespoke already, though a piece of old beef will serve to breakfast, yet a man would be glad of a chicken to supper; the clerk I hope understands no hebrew, and cannot write backward what he hath writ forward already, and then I am well enough: 'tis but a month
at most, if that were gone my venture comes in with her two for one, 'tis use enough a conscience for a brother if he had a conscience. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia as one door, Simonides, courtiers at the other.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Gentlemen courtiers.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: All your servants vowed lady.
O I shall kill myself with infinite laughter!
Will nobody take my part?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: An't be a laughing business
Put it to me, ●●me one of the best in Europe.
My father died last 〈◊〉, I have the most cause.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: You ha' picked out such a time sweet gentlemen
To make y●u● spleen a banquet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O the jest lady!
I have a jaw stands ready fort, ●l'e gape,
Half way and meet it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My old husband
That cannot say his prayers out for jealousy
And madness, at your coming first to woe me.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: 1 courtier
sp.l: Go on.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: On, on.

sp.speaker: E●g.
sp.l: Takes counsel with the secrets of all art
To make himself youthful ●gen.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: How youthful, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A man of forty five he would fain seem to be
Or scarce so much if he might have his will indeed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I but his white hairs they'll betray his hoariness.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Why there you are wide, he's not the man you take him for,
Nay will you know him when you see him again,
There will be five to one laid upon that.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Nay you did well to laugh faintly there,
I promise you I think he'll out live me now,
And deceive law and all.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Merry gout forbid.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You little think he was at fencing school
At four o'clock this morning.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How at fencing school?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Else give no trust to woman.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: By this light
I do not like him then, he's like to live
Longer than I, for he may kill me first now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: His dancer now came in as I met you.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: His dancer too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: They observe turns and hours with him▪
The great French rider will be here at ten
With his curvetting horse.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: These notwithstanding.
His hair and wrinkles will betray his age.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I'm sure his head and beard as he has ordered it
Looks not past fifty now heel bringt to forty
Within these four days for 9 times an hour at least
He takes ● black lead comb and combs it over.
Three quarters of his beard is under fifty,
There's but a little tuft of fourscore leftEnter Lisander.
All of one side which will be black by Monday,
And to approve my truth ●●e where he coms?
Laugh softly gentlemen, and look upon him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now by this hand he's almost black ith' mouth indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: He should die shortly then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Marry methinks he dies too fast already,
For he was all white but a week ago.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: O this same coney white takes an excellent black,
Too soon a mischief on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: He will beguile us all
If that little tuft northward turn black too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay sir I wonder 'tis so long a turning.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: May be some fairy's child held forth at midnight
Has pissed upon that side.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Is this the beard?

sp.speaker: Lis
sp.l: Ah sirrah my young boys I shall be for you,
This little m●ngle tuft takes up more time
Than all the beard beside, come you a-wooing
And I alive and lusty? you shall find
An alteration, Jack boys I have a spirit yet,
And I could match my hair to't, there's the fault,
And can do offices of youth yet lightly.
At least I will do though it pain me a little
Shall not a man for a little foolish age
Enjoy his wife to himself, must young court ti●s
Play tomboys tricks with her, and he live, ha?
I have blood that will not bear't, yet I confess
I should be at my prayers, but where's the dancer there. Ent. Dan

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come, come, come, one trick a day,
And I shall soon recover all again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Slight and you laugh too loud, we are all discovered gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And I have a scurvy ginny laugh a mine own.
Will spoil all I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Marry take heed sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay and I should be hanged I can't leave it, pup. there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Peace o peace!

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come I am ready sir.
I hear the church books lost where I was born to,
And that shall set me back one and twenty years
There is no little comfort left in that,
And my three court codlings that look parboiled,
As ●if they came from Cupid's scalding house.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: He means me specially I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: What trick will your old worship learn this morning sir?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Marry a trick if thou couldst teach a man
To keep his wife to himself, I'd fain learn that.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: That's a hard trick for an old man specially
The horse trick comes the nearest.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Thou sayst true, i'faith
They must be horsed indeed, else there's no keeping on 'em
And horse play at fourscore is not so ready.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Look you here's your worship's horse trick sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Nay say not so,
'Tis none of mine I fall down horse and man,
If I but offer at it.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: My life for yours sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Sayest thou me so.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Well offered by my viol sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: A pox of this horse trick, t'as played the jade with me
And given me a wrinch ith' back.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Now here's your i●turne, and your trick above ground.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Prithee no more, unless thou hast a mind
To lay me underground, one of these tricks
Enough in a morning.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: For your galliard sir
You are complete enough, I and may challenge
●●e proudest coxcomb of 'em all, I'll stand too●.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Faith and I've other weapons for the rest too,
●●ve prepared for 'em, if ere I take
〈◊〉 Gregory's here again.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O I shall burst, I can hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: He spoils all.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The devil and his grinners are you come.
Bring forth the weapons we shall find you play,
All feats of youth to Jack boys, feats of youth.
And these the weapon, drinking, fencing, dancing,
Your own road ways you glisterpipes, I'm old you say
Yes parlous old kids and you mark me well,
This beard cannot get children, yond lank suckeggs ,
Unless such weasels come from court to help us
We will get our own bats, you lecherous dogboltsEnter with glasses.
Well said down with 'em now we shall see your spirits
What dwindle you already?

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: I have no quality.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nor I, unless drinking may be reckoned
For one.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Why Sim it shall.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Come dare you choose your weapon now.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: I dancing sir and you will be so hasty.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: We're for you sir.

sp.speaker: ●. Courtesan
sp.l: Fencing I.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: We'll answer you to.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm for drinking your wet weapon there.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: That wet one has cost m●ny a princox life
And I will send it through you with a powder.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Let come with a Pox● I care not so't be drink.
I hope my gu●s will hold, and that's ●een all
A gentleman can look for of such trillibubs.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: P●●y the first weapon, come strike, strike I say
yes, yes, you shall be first, I'll observe court rulesA ga●●ard l●mini●rd
Always the worst goes foremost, so 'twill prove I hope
So sir, you've spit your poison, now come I,
Now forty years ago backward and assist me
Fall from me half my age but for three minutes,
That I may feel no crick, I will put fair fort
Although I hazard twenty sciaticas
So I have hit you.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: You've done well i'faith sir,

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If you confess it well 'tis excellent
And I have hit you soundly, I am warm now,
The second weapon instantly.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: What so quick sir, will you not allow yourself a breathing time?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I've breath enough at all times, lucifer's musk cod
To give your perfumed worship 3. Venies,
A sound old man puts his thrust better home
Then a spiced young man, there I.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Then have at you fourscore.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You l●e twenty I hope, and you shall find it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'm glad I missed this weapon, I had an eye
Popped out ere this time, or my two butter teeth
Thrust down my throat instead of a flap dragon.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: There's two, peptwizle.

sp.speaker: Dancing-master
sp.l: Excellently touched sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Had ever man such luck, speak your opinion gentlemen

sp.speaker: Sim.
