sp.l: Methinks your luck's good that your eyes are in still,
Mine would have dropped out like a pig's half toasted.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: There wants a third and there 'tis again.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: The devil has steeled him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What a strong fiend is jealousy?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Your dispatched bear whelp.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now comes my weapon in.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Here toad stool, here.
'Tis with you and I must play these 3. wet venies.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Vennis in Venice glasses, let 'em come
They'll bruise no flesh I'm sure, nor break no bones.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Yet you may drink your eyes out sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I but that's nothing then they go voluntarily, I do not
love to have 'em thrust out whether they will or ●●●

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Here's your first weapon du●k● meat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How, a Dutch what you call 'em.
St●●d of a German falchion, a shrewd weapon;
And of all things, hard to be taken down,
Yet down it must, I have a nose goes in to't
I shall drink double I think.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: The sooner off Sim.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I'll pay you speedily — with a trick.
I learned once amongst drunkards, here's half pike.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Half pike comes well after Dutch what you call 'em,
They'd never be asunder by their good will.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Well pulled of an old fellow.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: O but your fellows
Pull better at a rope.

sp.speaker: 1 courtesan
sp.l: There's a hair Sim.
In that glass.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: An't be as long as a halter down it goe●
No hair shall cross me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I make you stink worse than your polecats do.
●eeres long sword your last weapon.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No more weapons.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Why how now Sim bear up, thou sham'st us all else.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Light I shall shame you worse and I stay longer.
I ha' got the scotony in my head already
The whimsy, you all turn round, do not you dance gallants.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Pish what's all this? why Sim look the last venny

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No more venies goes down here, for these 2. are coming up again.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Out the disgrace of drinkers.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes 'twill out,
Do you smell nothing yet?

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Smell.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Farewell quickly then it will do if I stay. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1. Co●r.
sp.l: A foil go with thee.

sp.speaker: Lis●.
sp.l: What shall we put down youth at her own virtues?
Beat folly in her own ground wondrous much
Why may not we be held as full sufficient
To love our own wives, then get our own children
And live in free peace till we be dissolved?
For such spring butterflies that ●●e gawdy winged,
But no more substance than these shamble flies
Which butchers boys snap between sleep and waking,
Come but to crush you once you are all but maggots,
For all your beamy out sides. Enter Cleanthes

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Here's Cleanthes,
He comes to chide let him alone a little,
Our cause will be revenged, look, look his face
Is set for stormy weather, do but mark
How the clouds gather in't, 'twil pour down straight.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Methinks I partly know you, that's my grief
Could you not all be lost that had been handsome,
But to be known at all 'tis more than shameful,
Why was not your name wont to be Lisander?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis so still coz.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Judgement defer thy coming, else this man's miserable.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I told you there would be a shower anon.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: We'll in and hide our noddles. Exeunt courtiers and Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What devil brought this colour to your mind.
Which since your childhood I ne'er saw you weare●
You were ever of an innocent gloss
Since I was ripe for knowledge, and would you lose it
And change the livery of saints and angels
For this mixed monstrousness, to force a ground
That has been so long hallowed like a temple,
To bring forth fruits of earth now, and turn black
To the wild cries of lust, and the complexion
Of sin in act, lost and long since repented;
Would you begin a work ne'er yet attempted;
To pull time backward?
See what your wife will do, are your wits perfect?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: My wits.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I like it ten times worse for t'ad been safer
Now to be mad, and more excusable.
I hear you dan●e ●gen and do strange follies.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I must confess I have been put to some co●●●

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And yet you are not mad, pray say not so
Give me that comfort of you that you are mad
That I may think you are at worst, for if
you are not mad, I then must guess you have
The first of some disease was never heard of,
Which may be worse than madness, and more fearful,
You'd weep to see yourself else, and your care
To pray would quickly turn you white again.
I had a father had he lived his month out
But to h● seen this most prodigious folly,
There needed not the law to have cut him off:
The sight of this had proved his executioner, and broke his heart,
He would have held it equal
Done to a sanctuary, for what is age
But the holy place of life, chapel of ease
For all men's wearied miseries, and to rob●
That of her ornament, it is accursed,
As from a priest to steal a holy vestment,
● and convert it to a sinful covering. Exit Lisander.
I see t'has done him good, blessing go with it,Enter Eugenia.
Such as may make him pure again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Twas bravely touched i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O● you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Exceedingly well handled.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis to you I come, he fell but i'my way.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You m●●kd his beard cousin.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Mark me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Did you ever see a hair so changed?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I must be forced to wake her loudly to,
The devil has rocked her so fast asleep, strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: D● you call sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Whore.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be I ne'er so well
I must be sick of thee, thou'rt a disease
That stickest to th' heart, as all such women are.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What ails our kindred?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Bless me she sleeps still, what a dead modesty is i'this woman?
Will never blush again, look on thy work,
But with a Christian eye, 'twould turn thy heart
Into a shower of blood to be the cause
Of that old man's destruction, think upon't
ruin eternally, for through thy loose folly's
Heaven has found him a faint servant lately,
His goodness has gone backward, and engendered
With his old sins again, has lost his prayers
And all the tears that were companions with 'em
And like a blind fold man, giddy and blinded
Thinking he goes right on still, swerves but one foot
And turns to the same place where he set out●
So he that took his farewell of the world
And cast the joys behind him out of sight,
Summed up his hours, made even with time and men
Is now in heart arrived at youth again;
All by thy wildness thy too hasty lust
Has driven him to this strong apostasy,
Immodesty like thine was never equalled
I've heard of women, (Shall I call 'em so)
Have welcomed suitors ere the corpses were cold,
But thou thy husband living, thou art too bold.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well have you done now sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Look, look she smiles yet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: All this is nothing to a mind resolved,
Ask any woman that, she'll tell you so much
You have only shown a pretty saucy wit,
Which I shall not forget nor to requite it,
You shall hear from me shortly:

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Shameless woman,
I take my counsel from thee 'tis too honest
And leave thee wholly to thy stronger master,
Bless the sex of thee from thee, that's my prayer
Were all like thee so impudently common,
No man would be found to wed a woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I'll fit you gloriously he that attempts to take away my pleasure,
I'll take away his joy, and I can sure
His conceald father pays ●ort, I'll e'en tell.
Him that I mean to make my husband nextEnter Simonides
And he shall tell the Duke, — mass here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: H●s had about with me too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What no? since sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: A flirt, a little flirt, he called me strange names
but I near minded him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You shall quit him sir when he as little minds you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I like that well.
I love to be revenged when no one thinks of me.
There's little danger that way,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: This is it then
H● you shall strike your stroke shall be profound.
And yet your foe not gu●sle who gave the wound.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: A my troth I love to give such wounds. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter clown, Burler, bailiff, tailor, cook, drawer, wench.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Welcome gentlemen, will you not draw here, will you drink at do●e gentlemen?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O● the summer airs best!

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: What wine will please you drink gentlemen?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Declare sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What you're all sped already bullies?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: My w●d lowes a●h spit and half ready lad, a turn or too more and I have done with her.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then cook I hope you have basted her before this time.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: And stuck her with rosemary too, to sweeten h●, she was t●i●●ed ●er● she came to my hands what an old piece of flesh of fifty nine eleven moths and upwards, she must needs be flyblown.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Put her off put her off, though you lose by her● the weathers hot.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Why drawer? Enter drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: By and by, here gentlemen, here's the quintessence of Greece, the sages never drunk better grape.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
Sir the mad Greeks of this age ●a● taste their Palermo
as well as the sage Greeks did before 'em, fill lick spigot.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Ad imum sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My friends I must doubly invite you all the fifth of the next month, to the funeral of my first wife, and to the marriage of my second. my two to one this is she.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I hope some of us will be ready for the funeral of our wives by that time, to go with thee, but shall they be both of a day?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O best of all sir, where sorrow and joy meet together, one will help away with another the better▪ besides there will be charges saved too● the same rosemary that serves for the funeral, will serve for the wedding.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How long do you make account to be a widower sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Some half an hour, long enough a conscience.
Come, come, let's have some agility, is there no music in the house?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Yes sir, ●eere are sweet wire drawers in the house.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: O that makes them and you seldom part, you are wine drawers, and they wire drawers.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: And both govern by the peg● too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And you have pipes in your consort too.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: And sackbuts too sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But the heads of your instruments differ, yours are hogsheads their cittern and gittern heads.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: All wooden heads there they meet again.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Bid 'em strike up, we'll have a dance, Gnothoes come thou shalt fool it too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No dancing with me, we have Siren here.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Siren, 'twas Hiren the fair Greek man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Five drachmas of that, I say Siren the fair Greek, and so are all fair Greeks.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: A match, five drachmas her name was Hiren.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Sirens name was Siren for 5. Drachmas.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Take heed what you do Gnothoes.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do not I know our own country women Siren and Nell of Greece, two of the fairest Greeks that ever were.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: That Nell was Helen of Greece too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
As long as she tarried with her husband she was Ellen, but after she came to Troy she was Nell of Troy, or bonny Nell
whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Why did she grow shorer when she came to Troy?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: S●e grow longer if you mark the story, when she grew to be an ell sh●● was de●p●● then any yard of Troy could reach by a quarter: there was Cressid was Troy weighed, and N●ll was avoirdupois, she held more by four ounces then Cressida.

sp.speaker: Bailiff
sp.p: They say she caused many wounds to be given in Troy▪

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: True, she was wounded there herself, and cured again by plaster of Paris, and ever since that has been used to stop holes with. Enter drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Gentlemen if you be disposed to be merry, the music is ready to strike up, and here's a consort of mad Greeks, I know not whether they be men or women, or between both, they have what you call 'em vizards on their faces.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Visard's goodman lickspiggot.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: If they be wise women they may be wizards too.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: They desire to enter amongst any merry company of gentlemen good fellows for a strain or too. Old women.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: We'll strain ourselves with 'em say, let 'em come Gnothoes: now for the honour of Epire. Dance.

div.stage: She dancing with me, we have Siren here.
The dance of old women mas●t, then offer to take the men● they agree all but Gnothoes: he fits with his wench after they whisper.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I so kind then every one his wench to his several room●gn●thoes we are all provided now as you areExeunt each with his w●f●manet Gnothoes wife unmasked.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I shall have two it seems away I have Siren here already

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What a mermaid?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No but a maid horse face, o old woman is it you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes 'tis I, all the rest have gu●d themselves, and taken their own wauls, and shall know that they have done more than they can well answer, but I pray you, husband what are you doing?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Faith thus should I do if thou wert dead● old Ag. and thou hast not long to live ●me sure, we have Siren 'Here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Art thou so shameless whilst I am living to keep one under my nose.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
No ag I do prize her far above thy nose, if thou wouldst lay me both thine eyes in my hand to boot, I'll not leave her, art
not ashamed to be seen in a tavern, and hast scarce a fortnight to live, o old woman what art thou, must thou find no time to think of thy end?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O unkind villain.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And then sweet heart thou shalt have two new gowns, and the best of this old old woman's shall make thee raiments for the working ●ay●s.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O rascal dost thou quarter my clothes already too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Her roughs will serve thee for nothing but to wash dishes, for thou shalt have nine of the new fashion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Impudent villain, shameless harlot.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You may hear she never wore any but rails all her life time

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let me come I'll tear the strumpet from him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Dar'st thou call my wife strumpet, thou preterpluperfect tense of a woman, I'll make thee do penance in the sheet thou shalt be buried in, abuse my choice, my two to one.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No unkind villain I'll deceive thee yet,
I have a reprieve for five years of life,
I am with child.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Cud so Gnothoes● I'll not tarry so long, five years, I may bury two husbands by that time.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas give the poor woman leave to talk, she with child, I with a puppy, as long as I have thee by me, she shall not be with child I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The law and thou and all shall find I am with child.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll take my corporal oath I begat it not, and than thou diest for adultery.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No matter that will ask some time in the proof.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O you'd be stoned to death would you, all old women would die a that fashion with all their hearts, but the law shall overthrow you, the tother way first.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Indeed if it be so, I will not linger so long Gnothoes.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Away, away, some butcher has got it, 'tis but a cushion I warrant thee, the old woman is loath to depart, she never sung other tune in her life.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: We will not have our noses board with a cushion if it be so.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Go, go thy ways thou old almanac, at the 28. day of December e'en almost out of date, down on thy knees, and make
thee rea● 〈…〉 ●e of thy clothes to buy thee a death's head, and p●● upon thy middle finger, your least considering bawds do so much; be not thou worse though thou art an old woman as she is, I am cloyed with oily stock fish, here's a young perch is sweeter meat by half, prithee die before thy day if thou canst, that thou mayst not be counted a witch.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No, thou art a witch and I'll prove it, I said I was with child, thou knewest no other but by sorcery, thou saidst it was a cushion and so it is, thou art a witch fort, I'll be sworn to't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I told thee 'twas a cushion, go get thy sheet ready, we'll see thee buried as we go to church to be married. Ex.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay I'll follow thee, and show myself a wife, I'll plague thee as long as I live with thee, and I'll bury some money before I die that my ghost may haunt thee afterwards. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Cleanthes.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What's that? o nothing but the whispering wind,
Breathes through you churlish hawthorn that grew rude
As if it chid the gentle breath that kissed it,
I cannot be too circumspect, too careful
For in these woods lies hid all my lives treasure,
Which is too much ever to fear to lose.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Though it be never lost, and if our watchfulness
Ought to be wise and serious against a thief
That comes to steal our goods, things all without us,
That proves vexation often more than comfort,
How mighty ought our providence to be
To prevent those? if any such there were
That come to rob our bosom of our joys,
That only makes poor man delight to live:
●sh●, I'm too fearful fie, fie, who can hurt me?
But 'tis a general cowardice that shakes,
The nerves of confidence, he that hides treasure
Imagines every one thinks of that place
When 'tis a thing least minded, nay let him change
The place continually where ere it keeps,
There will the fear keep still, yonder's the store houseEnter Hippolita.
Of all my comfort now, and see it sends forth
A dear one, to me, pre●ious chief of women,
How does the good old soul, has he fed we●?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Be ●●rew me sir he made the heartiest meal today
Much good may't do ●i● health.

sp.speaker: Clean
sp.l: A blessing on them,
Both for thy news and wish.

sp.speaker: Eip.
sp.l: His stomach sir
Is bettered wondrously since his concealment.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Heaven has a blessed work in't, come we're safe here
I prithee call him forth, the airs much wholesomer.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Father,
How sweetly sounds the voice of a good woman? Ent. Leonides.
It is so seldom heard that when it speaks
It ravishes all fences.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Lifts of honour,
Ju● a joy weeps to see you, 'tis so full
So fairly fruitful,
I hope to see you often and returne●
Loaden with blessings, st●ll to pour on some●
I find 'em all in my contented peace,
And lose not one in thousands, they're dispersed
So gloriously I know not which are brightest
I find 'em as angels are found by legions;
First in the love and honesty of a wife,
Which is the first and chiefest of all temporal blessings,
Next in yourself, which is the hope and joy
Of all any actions, my affairs, my wishes,
And lastly which crowns all, I find my soul
Crowned with the peace of 'em, th'eternal riches
Man's only portion, for his heavenly marriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rise thou art all obedience, love and goodness,
I dare say that which thousand fathers cannot.
And that's my precious comfort, never son
Was in the way more of celestial rising,
Thou art so made of such ascending virtue
That all the powers of hell cannot sink thee. A Horne.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What wast disturbed my joy?
Clean did you not hear,
As afar off?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What my excellent consort. Clean. Nor you.

sp.speaker: ●●p
sp.l: I heard a —A horn.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Hark again.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bless my joy,
What ails it on a sudden?

sp.speaker: Clea●.
sp.l: Now since lately.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but a symptom of thy care man.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Alas you do not hear well.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What wast daughter?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I heard a sound twice. A horn.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Hark, louder and nearer:
In for the precious good of virtue, quick sir.
Lowder and nearer yet, at hand at hand;
A hunting here 'tis strange, I never
Knew game followed in these woods before.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Simonides, courtiers, and executioner.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Now let 'em come and spare not.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis, is't not the Duke, look sparingly?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis her but what of that, alas take heed sir,
Your care will overthrow us.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Come. it shall not,
Let's set a pleasant face upon our fears,
Though our hearts shake with horror, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Prithee proceed,
I'm taken with these light things infinitely,
Since the old man's decease; ha so they parted, ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Wh●●ow should I believe this, look, he's merry
As if he had no such charge? one with that care
Could never be so still, he holds his temper,
And 'tis the same still with no difference
He brought his father's corpse to'th grave with,
He laughed thus then you know.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Ay, he may laugh my lord;
That s●ower but how he glories in his cunning,
And perhaps done more to advance his wit,
Than to express affection to his father,
That only he his over reached the law.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He tells you right, my lord, his own cousin germane
Revealed it first to me, a free tongued woman,
and very excellent at telling secrets.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: If a contempt can be so neatly carried,
It gives me cause of wonder.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Troth my lord,
'Twill prove a delicate cozening, I believe:
I'd have no scrivener offer to come near it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cleanthes.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My loved lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not moved a whit,
Constant to lightning still, 'tis strange to meet you
Upon a ground so unfrequented sir:
This does not fit your passion, your for mirth
Or I m●st●k you much.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: But finding it
Grow to a noted imperfection in me,
For any thing too much is vicious;
I come to these disconsolate walks, of purpose
Only to dull and take away the edge on't.
I ever had a greater zeal to sadness,
A natural proportion, I confess my lord
Before that cheerful accident fell out●
If I may call a father's funeral cheerful
Without wrong done to duty or my love.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 〈◊〉 seems then you take pleasure i'these walks sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Contemplative content I do my lord
They bring into my mind oft meditations
So sweetly precious, that in the parting
● find shower of grace upon my cheeks,
They take their leave so feelingly.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Which is a kind of grave delight my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And i've small cause Cleanthes t'afford you the lest delight that has ● name.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now it begins to fadge.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.p: Peace thou art so greedy Sim.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: In your excess of joy you have expressed
Your rancour and contempt against my law:
Your smiles deserve fining, you've professed
Derision openly e'en to my face,
which might be death a little more incensed
You do not come for any freedom here
But for a project of your own,
But all that known to be contentful to thee,
Shall in the use prove deadly, your lives min●
If ever thy presumption do but le●d thee
Into these walks again, for that woman
I'll have 'em watched a purpose.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Now now, his colour ebbs and flows.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Mark hers too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O who shall bring food to the poor old man now,
Speak somewhat good sir or we're lost for ever?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O you did wondrous ill to call me again▪
There are not words to help us if I entreat
'Tis found, that will betray us worse than silence
Prithee let heaven alone, and let's say nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: You've struck 'em dumb my lord.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Look how guilt looks.
I would not have that fear upon my flesh
To save ten fathers.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: He is safe still, is he not?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O you do ill to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou'rt all goodness.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now does your grace believe?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis too apparent
Search, make a speedy search, for the imposture
Cannot be far off by the fear it sends.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: H●s the lapwings cunning, I'm afraid my lord
That cries most when she's farthest from the nest.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O we're betrayed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Betrayed sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: See my lord,
It comes out more and more still. Exeunt courtiers 〈◊〉 Si●.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Bloody thief,
Come from that place, 'tis sacred-homicide,
'Tis not for thy adulterate hands to touch it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O miserable virtue, what distress art thou in at this minute?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Help me thunder
〈◊〉 my powers lost, angels shoot plagues and help me:
Why are these men in health and I so heart sick?
Or why should nature have that power in me
To levy up a thousand bleeding sorrows
And not one comfort, only makes me lie
Like the poor mockery of an earthquake here?
Panting with horror, and have not so much force in all my vengeance.
To shake a villain off a me.

div.stage: Enter courtiers Simonides, Leonides.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Use him gently and heaven will love you fort.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Father, o father now I see thee full
In thy affection, thou'rt a man of sorrow
But reverently becomest it, that's my comfort.
Extremity was never better graced
Then with that look of thine, o let me look still
For I shall lose it, all my joy and strength
Is e'en eclipsed together, I transgressed
Your law my lord, let me receive the sting on●
Be once just sir, and let the offender die
He's innocent in all, and I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your grace knows when affection only speaks
Truth is not always there, his love would draw
An undeserved misery on his youth,
And wrong a peace resolved, on both parts sinful;
'Tis, I am guilty of my own concealment
And like a worldly coward injured heaven
With fear to go to't, now I see my fault,
And am prepared with joy to suffer fort.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Go give him quick dispatch, let him see death
And your presumption sir shall come to judgement. Exeunt with Leonides.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He's going, o he's gone sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Let me rise.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why do you not then, and follow?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I strive fort
Is their no hand of pity that will ease me
And take this villain from my heart a while?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alas he's gone.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A worse supplies his place then,
● weight more ponderous, I cannot follow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O misery of affliction.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: They will stay
Till I can come, they must be so good ever
Though they be ne'er so cruel,
My last leave must 〈◊〉 t●ken think a that,
And this last blessing given, I will not lose
That for a thousand consorts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That hopes wretched.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The inutterable stings of fortune,
All griefs are to be born, save this alone;
This like a headlong torrent over turns the frame of nature,
For he that gives us life first, as a father,
Locks all his natural sufferings in our blood, to
The sorrows that he feels, are our heads,
They are incorporate to us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Noble sir.

sp.speaker: Clea●.
sp.l: Let me behold him well.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou shouldst be good,
Or thou'rt a dangerous substance to be lodged
So near the heart of man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What means this, dear sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To thy trust only was this blessed secret
Kindly committed, 'tis destroyed, thou seest
What follows to be thought on't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Miserable;
Why here's th'unhappiness of woman still,
That having forfeited in old times their trustEnter Eugenia.
Now makes their faiths suspected that are just.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What shall I say to all my sorrows then,
That look for satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, cousin

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How ill dost thou become this time?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ha. ha, ha.
Why that's but your opinion, a young wench
Becomes the time at all times.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now coz we're even, and you be remembered
You left a strumpet and a whore at home with me,
And such fine field bed words, which coul● not cost you
Less than a f●ther.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Is it come that way?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Had you an uncle
He should go the same way too.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O eternity
What monster is this fiend in labour with?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: An ass colt with two heads, that's she and you:
I will not lose so glorious a revenge.
Not to be understood in't: I betray him,
And now we're even, y'ad best keep you so.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Is there not poison yet enough to kill me?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O sir, forgive me, it was I betrayed him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The fellow of my heart 'twill speed me then.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Her tears that never wept, and mine own pity
E'en cozened me together; and stole from me
This secret, which fierce death should not have purchased.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Nay then we're at an end, all we are false ones,
And ought to suffer, I was false to wisdom
In trusting woman, thou wert false to faith
In uttering of the secret, and thou false
To goodness in deceiving such a pity:
We are all tainted some way but thou worst,
And for thy infectious spots ought to die first.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Pray turn your weapon sir upon your mistress,
I come not so ill friended; rescue servants.

div.stage: Enter Simonides, and courtiers.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Are you so whorishly provided?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes sir she has more weapons at command then one.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Put forward man, thou art most sure to have me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I shall be surer if I keep behind though.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now servants show your loves.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll show my love too a far off.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I love to be so courted, woe me there.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I love to keep good weapons though never fought
I'm sharper set within then I am without.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O gentlemen Cleanthes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Fight, upon him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thy thirst of blood proclaims thee now a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis dainty, next to procreation fitting,
I'd either be destroying men or getting. Enter officers

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.l: Forbear on your allegiance gentlemen
He's the Duke's prisoner, and we seize upon him
To answer this contempt against the law.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I obey fate in all things.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Happy rescue.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I would y'ad seized upon him a minute sooner, 'thad saved me a cut finger, I wonder how I came by't, for I never put my hand forth I'm sure, I think my own sword did cut it if truth were known; may be the wire in the handle, I have lived these five and twenty years and never knew what colour my blood was before I never durst eat oysters, nor cut peck loaves.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You have shown your spirits gentlemen, but you
Have cut your finger.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I the wedding finger too, ● pox on't.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.p: You'll prove a bawdy bachelor Sim, to have a cut upon your finger, before you are married.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll never draw sword again to have such
A jest put upon me.Exeunt

div.head: Act. v. scen. i.
div.stage: Sword and mace carried before them.
Enter Simonides, and the Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Be ready with your prisoner, we'll ●●t instantly ●n rise before leaven, or when we please: shall we not ●o low judges?

sp.speaker: Courtesan
sp.l: 'Tis committed
All to our power, censure and pleasure, now
The Duke hath made us chief lords of this sessions,
And we may speak by fits, or sleep by turns.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Leave that to us, but whatsoe'er we do
The prisoner shall be sure to be condemned,
sleeping or waking we are resolved on that
Before we set upon him. Eugenia.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Make you question
If not Cleanthes and one enemy
Nay a concealer of his father too.
A vild example in these days of youth.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If they were given to follow such examples
But sure I think they are not, howsoe'er
'Twas wickedly attempted, tha●s my judgements
And it shall pass whilst I am in power to sit,
Never by prince were such young judges made,
But now the cause requires it, if you mark it
He must make young or none● for all the old ones
Her father he hath sent a fishing, and my father's one●
I humbly thank his highness. Enter Eugenia

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Widows?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You almost hit my name, no gentlemen
You come so wondrous near it I admire you
For your judgement.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My wife that must be she.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My husband goes upon his last hour now.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: On his last legs I am sure.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: September the seventeenth
I will not bate an hour on't, and tomorrow
His latest hours expired.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Bring him to judgement,
The juries paneled and the verdict given
Ever he appears we have ta'en course for that.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And officers to attach the grey young man,
The youth of fourscore be of comfort 〈◊〉:
We shall no longer bosom January:
For that I will take order, and provide
For you a lusty April. Lisander and guardian.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: The month that ought indeed
To go before may.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Do as we have said,
Take a strong guard and bring him into court,
Lady Eugenia see this charge performed
That having his life forfeited by the law
He may relieve his soul.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Willingly
From shaven chins never came better justice
Than these new touched by reason.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What you do
Do suddenly we charge you, for we purpose to make but a short
Sessions, a new businessEnter Hippolita.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: The fair Hippolita, now what's your suits?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alas I know not how to style you yet,
To call you judges doth not suit your years
Nor heads and brains show more antiquity,
Yet sway yourselves with equity and truth
And I'll proclaim you reverent, and repeat
Once in my life ●ime I have seen grave heads
Placed upon young men's shoulders.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Hark she sl●u●s us,
And thinks to make us monstrous.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: Prove not so,
For yet methinks you bear the shapes of men.
Though nothing more than merely beautifeaus
To make you appear angels, but if crimson
Your name and power with blood and cruelty,
Suppress fair virtue and enlarge of old vice,
Both against heaven and nature, draw your sword
Make either will or humour turn the soul
Of your created greatness, and in that
Oppose all goodness. I must tell you there
You're more than monstrous, in the very act,
You change yourself to devils.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Shees a witch
Ha●ke she begins to conjure●

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Time you see
Is short much business now on foot, shall I
Give her her answer?

sp.speaker: 2. Courtier
sp.l: None upon the bench
More learnedly can do it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He, he, hem, then list
I wonder at thine impudence young housewife
That thou darest plead for such a base offender,
Conceal a father passed his time to die:
what son and heir would have done this but he?

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: I vow not I.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Because ye are parricides
And how can comfort be derived from such
That pity not their fathers?

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.p: You are fresh and fair, practise young women's ends when husbands are distressed provide them friends.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I'll set him forward fee thee
Some wives would pay for such a courtesy.Without fee.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Times of amazement what duty goodness dwell,
I sought for charity but knock at hell. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, with Lisander prisoner, a guard.

sp.speaker: Simonides.
sp.l: Eugenia com●.
Command a second guard
To bring Cleanthes in we'll not sit long.
My stomach strives to dinner.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now servants may a lady be so bold
To call your power so low?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: A mistress may,
She can make all things low, then in that language
There can be no offence.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: The times now come
Of manumissions take him into bonds,
And I am then at freedom.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: This the man,
He● hath left of late to feed on snakes,
His beards turned white again

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: Is't possible these gouty legs danced lately,
And shattered in a galliard?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Jealousy,
And fear of death can work strange prodigies.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: The nimble fencer this that made me tear
And traverse bout the chamber.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I and gave me
Those elbow healths the hangman take him fort:
They had almost fetched my heart out, the Dutch veny
I swallowed pretty well, but the half pike
Had almost prepared me but had I took
Being swollen I had cast my lungs out. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A FlemishEnter the Duke.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Peace the Duke.
Nay ba●●e your seats, who's that?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May't please your highness

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis old Lisander.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And brought in by his wife a worthy precedent
Of one that no way would offend the law.
And should not pass away without remark,
You have been looked for long.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: But never fit
To die till now my lord, my sins and I
Have been but newly parted, much ado
I had to get them leave me, or be taught
That difficult lesson how to learn to die.
I never thought there had been such an act
And 'tis the only discipline we are born for
All studies as are, are but as circular lines
And death the centre where they must all meet.
I now can look upon thee erring woman
And not be vexed with jealousy, on young men,
And no way envy their delicious health,
Pleasure and strength, all which were once mine own
And mine must be theirs one day.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have tamed him

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And know how to dispose him that my liege
Hath been before determined, you confess
Yourself of full age.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Yes and prepared to inherit

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your place above — Duke — away to death with him

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Of which the hangman's strengthCleanthes guard.
Shall put him in possession, 'tis still guard
To take me willing and in mind to die.
And such are when the earth grows weary of them
Most fit for heaven, the court shall make his mittimus
And send him thither presently ith' mean time.
sp.stage: Enter a guard with Cleanthes, Hippollita weeping after him.
sp.l: So see another person brought to the Barr.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: The arch malefactor.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: The grand offenders the most refractory
to call good orders, 'tis Cleanthes,
He.

sp.speaker: Sim●
sp.l: That would have sons grave fathers ere their fathers
Be sent unto their graves.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There will be expectation
In your severe pooceedings against him;
His act being so capital.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Fearful and bloody,
Therefore we charge these women leave the court
Lest they should stand to hear it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I in expectation
Of a most happy freedom. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I with the apprehension
Of a most sad and desolate widow hood. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: We bring him to the bar.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Hold up your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: More reverence to the place then to the person●
To the one I offer up a palm
Of duty and obedience showed us to heaven,
Imploring justice which was never wanting
Upon that bench whilst their own fathers sat:
But unto you, my hands contracted thus,
As threatening vengeance against murderers,
For they that kill in thought shed innocent blood
With pardon to your highness too much passion
Made me forget your presence and the place,
I now am called too▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: All one majesty
And power we have to pardon or condemn
Is now conferred on them.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And these we'll use
Little to thine advantage.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I expect it
And as to these I look no mercy from
And much less shown to entreat it, I thus now
Submit me the emblems of your power I mean
The sword and bench but my most reverend judges
Ere you proceed to sentence, for I know
You have given me lost, will you resolve me one thing?

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: So it be briefly questioned.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Show your honour,
D●y spends itself a pace.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My lords it shall
Resolve me then where are your filial tears
Your mourning habits and sad hearts become.
That should attend your father's funeral
Though the strick law which I will not accuse
Because a subject snatched away their lives
It doth not ba●r them to lament their deaths
Or if you cannot spare one s●d suspire
It doth not bid you laugh them to their graves
L●y subtle trains to antedate their years,
To be the sooner ceased of their estates.
O time of age where's that Aeneas now
Who letting all his jewels to the flames.
Forgetting country kindred treasure friends
Fortunes and all things save the name of son
Which you so much forget, go like Aeneas
Who took his bedrid father on his back
And with that sacred load (To him no burden)
Hewed out his way through blood, through fire, through
Even all the armed streets of bright burning Troy,
Only to save a father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: We have no leisure now
To hear lessons read from Virgil, we are passed school,
And all this time thy judges.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: 'Tis fit,
That we proceed to sentence.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: You are the mouth
And now 'tis fit to open.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Justice indeed
Should ever be close eared, and open mouthed
That is to hear him little, and speak much
Low then Cleanthes there is none can be
A good son and a bad subject, for if princes
Be called the people's fathers than the subjects
Are all his sons, and he that flouts the prince
Doth disobey his father, there year gone.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: And not to be recovered.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: And again.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: If he be gone once call him not again.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I say again this act of thine expresses
A double disobedience, as our princes
Are fathers, so they are our sovereigns too,
And he that doth rebel against sovereignty
Doth commit treason in the height of degree
And now thou art quite gone.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: Our brother in commission
Hath spoke his mind both learnedly and neatly,
And I can add but little, howsoever
It shall send him packing.
He that begins a fault that wants example
Ought to be made example for the fault.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A fault no longer can I hold myself
To hear vice upheld and virtue thrown downe●
A fault judge then, I desire where it lieth
In those that are my judges or in me
Heaven stand on my side pity love and duty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Where are they sir who sees them but yourself .

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Not you, and I am sure,
You never had the gracious eyes to see them,
You think you arraign me, but I hope
To sentence you at the bar.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: That would show brave.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: This were the judgement seat, we now
The heaviest crimes that ever made up
Unnaturalness in humanity,
You are found foul and guilty by a jury
Made of your father's curses, which have brought
Vengeance impending on you, and I now
Am forced to pronounce judgement on my judges.
The common laws of reason and of nature
Condemn you ipso facto, you are parricides,
And if you marry will beget the liar
Who when you're grown to full maturity
Will hurry you their fathers to their graves;
Like traitors you take counsel from the living
of upright judgement, you would rob the bench:
Experience and discretion snatched away
From the earth's face, turn all into disorder,
Imprison virtue, and enfranchise vice,
And put the sword of justice into the hands of
Boys and mad men.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Well, well have you done sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have spoke my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then I'll begin and end.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis time I now begin,
Where your commission ends,
Cleanthes you come from the bar
Because I know you're severally disposed;
I here invite you to an object will no doubtRecorders. Old men.
Work in you contrary effects.
Music.

div.stage: Music, sons and the old men appear.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Pray heaven I dream not, sure he moves, talks comfortably, as joy can wish a man, if he be changed
Far above from me, he is not ill intreated
His face doth promise fullness of content
And glory hath a part in't.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O my son.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You that can claim acquaintance with these lads
Talk freely.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I can see none there that's worth one hand to you from me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: These are thy judges and by their grave law
I find thee clear, but these delinquents guilty:
You must change places for 'tis so decreed
Such just pre-eminence hath thy goodness gained
Thou art the judge now, they the men arraigned.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: H●ers fine dancing gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Courtesan
sp.l: Is thy father amongst them?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O a pox I saw him the first thing I looked on
Alive again, flight I believe now a father
Hath as many lives as a mother.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis full as blessed as 'tis wonderful
O bring me back to the same law again
I am fouler than all these, cease on me officers
And bring me to new sentence.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What's all this?
A fault not to be pardoned
Unnaturalness is but sun's shadow to it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am glad of that, I hope the case may alter
And I turn judge again.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Name your offence.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: That I should be so vild
As once to think you cruel.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is that all?
'Twas pardoned ere confessed, you that have sons
If they be worthy hear my challenge then.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I should have one amongst them had he had grace
To have retained that name.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: I pray you father. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That name I know
Hath been long since forgotten.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I find but small comfort in remembering it now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cleanthes take your places with these grave father
And read what in that table is inscribed
Now set these at the bar.
And read Cleanthes to the dread and terror
Of disobedience and unnatural blood.

sp.speaker: Cle●n.
sp.l: It is decreed by the grave and learned
Counsel of Epire, that no son and heir
Shall be held capable of his inheritance
At the age of one and twenty, unless he be at that time
As nature in obedience, manners and goodness.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Sure I shall never be at full age then,
Though I live to an hundred years, and that's nearer by twenty,
Then the last statute allowed.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtesan
sp.l: A terrible act.
sp.p: Moreover is enacted that all sons aforesaid, whom either this law for their live grace, whom it shall reduce into the true method of duty, virtues and affection; and relate their trial and approbation from Cleanthes the son of Leonides — from me my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: From none but you as fullest, proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p:
Whom for his manifest virtues, we make such
judge and censure of youth and the absolute reference of life and manners.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This is a brave world, when a man should be
Selling land he must be learning manners,
Is't not my masters? Eugenia.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia.

sp.speaker: E●g.
sp.l: What's here to do, my suitors at the bar
The old bawd shines again, o miserable! She sounds.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Read the law over to her 'twill awake her
'Tis one deserves small pity.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Last it is ordained that all such wives now whatsoever that shall design the husband's death to be soon rid of them and entertain suitors in their husband's life time.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You had best read that a little louder.
For if any thing that will bring her to herself again, and find her tongue.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Shall not presume on the penalty of our heavy displeasure to marry within ten years after.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tha● l●wes too long by nine years and a half.
I'll take my death upon't, so shall most women.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And those incontinent women so offending
To be judge and censured by Hippolita,
Wife to Cleanthes. Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Of all the rest I'll not be judge by her. Enter Hip.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Ah here she comes, let me prevent thy joys, prevent them but in part and hide the rest, thou hast not strength enough to bear them else.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Leonides. She faints.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I feared it all this while.
I knew it was passed thy power Hippolita,
What contrariety is in women's blood?
One faints for spleen and anger, she for grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Of sons and wives we see the worst and best,
My future ages yield Hippolitas
M●ny, but few like thee Eugenia.
Let no Simonides henceforth have a fame
But all bl●st sons live in Cleanthes' nameMusic.
Ha what strange kind of melody was that?
Yet give it entrance whatsoever it be.Music
This day is all devout to liberty.

div.stage: Clo. etc. enter music one carrying a bride cake, the clown, the rest with t●●m ol● wom●n.
Enter clown, and w●nch, the rest with the old women, the clowns wife, music, and a b●ide cake ● the wedding.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Fiddlers crowd on, crowd on, let no man lay a block in your way, crowd on I say.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Stay the crowd a while, let's know the reason
Of this jollity.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Sirrah do you know where you are?

sp.speaker: Clo●
sp.p: Yes sir, I am here, now here, and now here again sir.

sp.speaker: Ais.
sp.p: Your hats too high crowned the Duke in presence.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The Duke (As he is my sovereign) I do give him two crowns for it, and that's ●quall change all the would over, 〈◊〉 am lord of the day (Being my marriage day the second) I do advance-bonnet crowd on a fore.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good sir a few words if you'll vouchsafe 'em
Or will you be forced?

sp.speaker: Clo●
sp.p: Forced, I would the Duke himself would say so.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I think he dares sir, and does, if you stay not
You shall be forced.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I think so my lord, and good reason too, shall not I stay when your grace says I shall, I were unworthy to be a bridegroom in any part of your highness' dominions then, will it please you to taste of the wedlock courtesy?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O by no means sir, you shall not deface
So fair an ornament for me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If your grace please to be cac●ted say so.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And which might be your fair bride sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: This is my two for one that must be uxor uxoris,
The remedy doloris, and the very syceum amoris.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And hast thou any else?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have an older my lord for other uses.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My lord I do observe a strange decorum here
These that do lead this day of jollity
Do march with music and most mirthful cheeks
Those that do follow sad, and woefully
nearer the haviour of a funeral
Than a wedding.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: 'Tis tr●e, pray expound that sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As the destiny of the day falls out my lord, one goes out to weddings another goes to hanging; and your grace, in the due consideration shall find 'em much alike, the one hath the ring upon her finger, the other a halter about her neck.
I take thee Beatrice says the bridegroom, I take thee Agatha says the hangman, and both say together to have and to hold till death do part us.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: This is not yet plain enough to my understanding.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If further your grace examine it, you shall find I show myself a dutiful subject and obedient to the law, myself (With these my good friends, and your good subjects) our old wives whose days are ripe, and their lives forfeit to the law only myself more forward than the rest, am already provided of my second choice.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O take heed sir, you'll run yourself into danger,
If the law finds yo● with two wives at once
Tears a shrewd premunire.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have taken leave of the ol● my lord. I have nothing to say to her, shees going to S●●, your grace knows whether better than I do, she has a strong wind with her, it stands full in her poop when you please let her disembogue.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: And the rest of her neighbours with her whom we present to the satisfaction of your highness' law.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And so we take our leaves and leave them to your highness, crowd on.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Stay. stay, you are too forward, will you marry?
And your wife ye● l●ving.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas she'll be dead before we can get to church, if your grace would set her in the way, I would dispatch her, I have a venture on●, which would return me, if your highness would make a little more h●st two for one.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come my lords we must sit again, here's a case
C●ves a mos● serious censure.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: N●w t●●y shall be dispatched out of the way.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: ● would they were gone once, the time goes away.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Which is the wife unto the forward bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am and it please your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Trust me a lusty woman, able bodied
And well blooded cheeks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O she paints my lord, she was a chamber maid once, and learned it of her lady.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Sure I think she cannot be so old.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly I think so too, and please your grace.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Two to one with your grace of that, she's threescore by the book.

sp.speaker: L●o.
sp.p: Peace sirrah you're too loud.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Take heed Gnothoes if you move the Duke's patience, 'tis an edge tool but a word and a blow, he cut● off your head.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Cut off my head, away ignorant, he knows it cost more in the hair, he does not use to cut off many such heads as mine, I will talk to him to, it he cut off my head, I'll give him my ears, I say my wife is at full age for the law, the clerk shall take his oath and the church book shall be sworn too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: My lords, I leave this sensure to you

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Then first this fellow does deserve punishment
For offering up a lusty able woman
Which may do service to the commonwealth,
Where the law craves one impotent and useless.

sp.speaker: Creon,
sp.l: Therefore to be severely punished
For thus attempting a second marriage
His wife yet living.

sp.speaker: Lis●
sp.l: Nay to have it trebled
That even the day and instant when he should mourn
As a kind husband to her funeral,
He leads a triumph to the scorn of it
Which unseasonable joy ought to be punished
With all severity.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The fiddles will be in a foul case too by and by.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay further it seems he has a venture
Of two for one at his second marriage
Which cannot be but a conspiracy
Against the former.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A mess of wise old men.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Sirrah what can you answer to all these?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
You're good old men and talk as age will give you leave; I would speak with the youthful Duke himself, he and I may
speak of things that shall be 30 or 40 years after you are dead and rotten, a●as you are here today and gone to S●a tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Du●.
sp.l: Intruth sir then I must be plain with you
The law that should take away your old wife from you
The which I do perceive was your desire,
Is void and frustrated so for the rest,
There has been since another parliament
Has cut it off.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I see your grace is disposed to be pleasant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes you might perceive that, I had not else
Thus dallied with your follies.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll talk further with your grace when I come
Back from church, in the mean time you know what to do
With the old woman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Stay sir unless in the mean time you mean
I c●use a ●●bber to be set up in your way
And hand you at your return.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: O gracious prince.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your old wives cannot die today by any
●●w of mine, for ought I can say too 'em
●●●y may by a new edict bury you,
And then perhaps you pay a new fine too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O gracious prince may he live a hundred years more.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: Your venture is not like to come in today gnothoes.

sp.speaker: Cl●.
sp.p: Give me the principal back.

sp.speaker: Cook,
sp.p: Nay by my troath we'll venture still, and I'm sure we have as ill a venture of it as you, for we have taken old wives of purpose, where that we had thought to have put away at this market, 〈◊〉 now we cannot utter a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well sirrah you were best to discharge
Your new charge and take your o●d one to you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O music, no music, but prove most doleful trumpets,
O bride no bride, but thou must prove a strumpet,
O venture, no venture, I have for one now none,
O wife, thy life is saved when I hope t'had been gone,
Case up your fruitless strings. no penny no wedding,
Case up thy maiden head, no priest no bedding,
Avant my venture it can ne'er be restored,
till Agg my old wife be thrown over board,
Then come again old Agg since it must be so,
Let bride, and venture with woeful music go.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What for the bride cake Gnothoes?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Let it be mouldy now 'tis out of season,
Let it grow out of date currant and reason,
Let it be chipped and chopped and given to chickens
No more is got by that, than William Dickins
Got by his wooden dishes.
Put up your plums as fiddlers put up pipes,
The wedding dashed the bridegroom
Weeps and wipes.
Fiddler's farewell and now without perhaps,
Put up your fiddles as you put up scraps.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: This passion has given some satisfaction yet,
My lord I think you'll pardon him now,
Withal the rest so they live honestly
With the wives they have.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O most freely, free pardon to all.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I we have deserved our pardons if we can live honestly with such reverent wives that have no motion in 'em but their tongues.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Heaven bless your grace, you're a just prince.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: All hopes dashed, the clarks duties lost, venture gone, my second wife divorced, and which is worst the old one come back again.
sp.l: Such voyages are made now adays, I will weep too salt
Of our nose, besides these two fountains of fresh water,
Your grace had been more kind to your young subjects.
Heaven bless, and mend your l●wes, that they do
Not gull your poor country men: fashion, but I am not
The first by forty that his been undone by the law,
'Tis but a folly to stand upon terms,
sp.p: I take my leave of your grace, as well as mine eyes will give me leave, I would they had been asleep in their beds when they opened 'em to see this day: come Agg, come Agg.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.p: Were not you all my servants?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: During your life as we thought sir, but our young master turned us away.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.p: How headlong villain wert thou in thy ruin?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I followed the fashion sir as other young men did,
If you have as we thought you had been
We should ne'er have come for this I warrant you,
We did not feed after the old fashion on beef
And mutton and such like.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Well what damage or charge you have run
Yourselves into by marriage, I cannot help
Nor deliver you from your wives, them you must keep
Yourselves shall again retain to me.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We thank your lordship for your love, and must thank ourselves for our bad bargains.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cleanthes you delay the power of law,
To be inflicted on these misgoverned men,
That filial duty have so far transgressed.

sp.speaker: Clean
sp.l: My lord I see a satisfaction
Meeting the sentence, even preventing it
Beating my words back in their utterance
See sir there's salt sorrow bringing forth fresh
And new duties (As the sea propagate)
The elephants have found their joints too, why
Here's humility able to bind up
The punishing hands of the severest masters
Much more the gentle fathers.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I had ne'er thought to have been brought so low as my knees again, but since there's no remedy, fathers, reverent fathers, as you ever hope to have good sons and heirs, a handful of pity we confess we have deserved more than we are willing to receive at your hands, though sons can never deserve too much of their fathers as shall appear afterwards.

sp.speaker: Creon
sp.l: And what way can you decline your feeding now?
You cannot retire to beeves and muttons sure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Alas sir you see a good pattern for that, now we have laid by our high and lusty meats, and are down to our many bones already.

sp.speaker: Creon.
sp.l: Well sir rise to vertues we'll bound you now,
You that were too weak yourselves to govern,
By others shall be governed.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Cleanthes,
I meet your justice with reconcilement
If there be tears of faith in woman's breast
I have received a myriad which confirms me
To find a happy renovation.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Here's virtue's throne
Which I'll embellish with my dearest jewels
Of love and faith, peace and affection,
This is the altar of my sacrifice,
Where daily my devoted knees shall bend
Age honoured shrine, time still so love you,
That I so long may have you in mine eye
Until my memory lose your beginning.
For you great prince, long may your fame survive,
Your justice and your wisdom never die,
Crown of your crown, the blessing of your land
Which you reach to her from your regent's hand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O Cleanthes had you with us tasted
The entertainment of our retirement
Feared and exclaimed on in your ignorance,
You might have sooner died upon the wonder
Then any rage or passion for our loss.
A place at hand we were all strangers in
So sphea●d about with music, such delights
Viands and attendance, and once a day
So cheered with a royal visitant
That oft times (Waking) our unsteady fantasies
Would question whether we yet lived or no
Or had possession of that paradise
Where angels be the guard.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Enough Leonides
You go beyond the praise, we have our end
And all is ended well, we have now seen
The flowers and weeds that grew about our court.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If these be weeds I'm afraid I shall wear none so good again as long as my father lives.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Only this gentleman we did abuse
With our own bosom we seemed a tyrant
And he our instrument look 'tis Cratilus. Discover the executioner.
The man that you supposed had now been travelled,
which we gave leave to learn to speak
And bring us foreign languages to Greece
All's joyed I see, let music be the crown,
And set it high, the good needs fear no law,
It is his safety, and the bad man's awe.

div.head: An exact and perfect catalogue of all the plays that were ever printed; together, with all the authors names; and what are comedies, histories, interludes, masks, pastorels, tragedies: and all these plays you may either have at the sign of the Adam and Eve, in little Britain; or, at the Ben Johnson's head in Thredneedle-street, over against the exchange.

row.cell: Changes, or love in a maze
Choice a good wife from a bad
Endymion, or the man in the moon
Enough as good as a feast
Henry the fifth, with the battle
If this be not a good play the devils in't
John K. of England, both parts
Knack to know an honest man
New way to pay old debts
New trick to cheat the devil
Rule a wife and have a wife
See me, or see me not
The longer thou livest, the more fool thou art
Trick to catch the old one
When you see me, you will know me

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
